componenttext:
Good morning. My name is Stephen, and I would be your conference facilitator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the UPS Investor Relations First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you for your cooperation. 
It is now my pleasure to turn the floor over to your host, Mr. Joe Wilkins, Investor Relations Officer. Sir, the floor is yours.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the UPS First Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. Joining me today are David Abney, our CEO; Richard Peretz, our CFO; along with International President, Jim Barber;  President of U.S. Operations, Myron Gray; and Chief Commercial Offi
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the UPS First Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. Joining me today are David Abney, our CEO; Richard Peretz, our CFO; along with International President, Jim Barber;  President of U.S. Operations, Myron Gray; and Chief Commercial Officer, Alan Gershenhorn. Also joining us today is Norman Brothers [ph], our General Counsel.
Before we begin, I want to review the safe harbor language. Some of the comments we'll make today are forward-looking statements that address our expectations for the future performance or results of operations of the company. These statements are subject to risks and uncertainties, which are described in detail in our 2014 Form 10-K and 2015 10-K. These reports are available on the UPS Investor Relations website and from the Securities and Exchange Commission. 
The webcast of today's call, along with a reconciliation of non-GAAP financial measures, are available on the UPS Investor Relations website. And just as a reminder, please ask only one question so that we may allow as many as possible to participate. 
Thanks for your cooperation. Now I will turn the call over to David.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Joe. I'm pleased to be here this morning to review another excellent quarter. I want to take a moment to say thank you to UPS employees around the world for their hard work and dedication in delivering more than 13% earnings per share growth this
componenttext:
Thanks, Joe. I'm pleased to be here this morning to review another excellent quarter. I want to take a moment to say thank you to UPS employees around the world for their hard work and dedication in delivering more than 13% earnings per share growth this quarter. 
The international segment sustained its momentum on its 5th consecutive quarter of double-digit operating profit growth. The U.S. domestic business also expanded operating margins as efficiency gains enhanced bottom line results, while Supply Chain & Freight performed slightly ahead of our expectations.
Our accelerated investments in the UPS network are improving business results. This is enabling us to deliver strong financial results despite the current mixed macro environment. In the U.S., GDP forecast continue to be revised downward, yet consumer spending remains the primary catalyst for growth in the economy and e-commerce sales have again exceeded expectations.
On the other hand, industrial production remains below 2015 levels. In Europe, economic expansion has slowed slightly, but the pace of growth remains healthy. While in Asia, the major economy showed positive signs of stabilization as exports from China improved in March. 
Despite these mixed economic conditions, we remain committed to making investments for growth and efficiency. We will continue to implement our enterprise strategy, providing UPS customers with increased choice, convenience and control.
During the quarter, we launched enhanced products to support customer's needs for earlier delivery. Our Next Day Air early now serves almost 30% more ZIP Codes, strengthening our leadership position in offering the earliest next-day deliveries.
We also increased our Worldwide Express small package offering to 23 new countries and territories. UPS now offers guaranteed delivery on the next possible business day to 88 countries around the world.
In addition to broadening our service portfolio for growth, we also are investing in our infrastructure with innovative technology in major facility expansions. The ability to combine our integrated network with the latest operating technology helps UPS deliver industry-leading margins and provides tremendous value to our customers.
ORION is a great example of how we use predictive analytics and big data to improve service while bending the cost curve lower. Our future plans for Orion will enhance the benefits for UPS and our customers. In fact, I recently had the great honor, on behalf of all UPSers, to accept the prestigious 2016 Fond-Zenaman [ph] Award recognizing ORION and UPS's leadership in operations research. 
In addition to innovation in honor of technologies like ORION, we're making major investments in new capacity and modernized facilities, both in the U.S. and Europe. In the U.S., we are expanding major facilities in Metro LA, Denver, Chicago and other areas around the country. In Europe, as part of our $2 billion European investment plan announced in 2014, we opened a larger automated hub in Lyon, France, tripling our capacity in the area.  And we also announced an automated facility expansion in Herne [ph], Germany.
Adding to these examples of our innovated infrastructure is our commitment to global leadership in alternative fuels. This quarter, we announced an additional $100 million investment to expand compressed natural gas in our delivery and facility network. Our alternative fuel vehicles are now 6% of our global fleet and have helped UPS reduce its annual use of conventional fuel by 10%.
We are well on our way to achieving our goal of driving 1 billion miles worldwide by 2017 with our alternative fuel vehicles. 
As we invest in the U.S. and abroad, the ability to grow our business is accelerated by global trade. Recently, the President signed the Trade Facilitation and Trade Enforcement Act. This important legislation is designed to modernize, strengthen and streamline cross-border trade, facilitating [indiscernible] of goods into the U.S. UPS strongly supports the expansion of free-trade around the world. We are developing additional solutions that assist buyers and sellers to transact business across borders. 
So in summary, the first quarter results demonstrate the differentiating value of our integrated network and global portfolio.
Our investments in technology and capacity are producing network efficiencies in giving us more control over the cost drivers in our business. And this is providing improved financial results. 
At UPS, we are innovating and investing to ensure we anticipate the needs of our 10 million customers.
Before Richard covers the quarterly financial results, I've asked Norm Broadus, our General Counsel, to provide an update on developments surrounding the central states proposed benefit reduction plan. Norm?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, David, and good morning. This is a topic that we first disclosed in our third quarter 2015 10-Q. The central state's plan proposes to make retirement benefit reductions to its participants, including certain UPS employees. When UPS withdrew from t
componenttext:
Thanks, David, and good morning. This is a topic that we first disclosed in our third quarter 2015 10-Q. The central state's plan proposes to make retirement benefit reductions to its participants, including certain UPS employees. When UPS withdrew from the fund in 2007, the [indiscernible] Collective Bargaining Agreement with the International Brotherhood Teamsters, we agreed to provide supplemental benefits in the event that certain benefits were lawfully reduced. 
As a reminder, in December 2014, Congress passed the Multiemployer Pension Reform Act, which for the first time ever, allowed multiemployer pension plans to reduce benefit payments to retirees, subject to specific guidelines written into the statute and government oversight. As a result of this law, the Central State Pension Fund submitted a benefit reduction plan for approval to the U.S. Department of Treasury in the fall of 2015.
As we explained in our 2015 10-K, we are challenging Central State's plan because we firmly believe that it does not comply with the law. According to this new statute, we currently expect the decision from the Department of Treasury on or before May 7. Unless there are some agreement to delay the process. Of course, Treasury could reject Central State's proposal, confirming our position. If this happens, the benefits paid from Central  States will not be reduced without further action. 
In the event these plans approved as proposed, we fully intend to continue challenging it and pursue all legal remedies available to UPS. As we gained additional information during the quarter, we continue to assess the possible impact of Treasury's review of the plan on UPS. This is a new law and the first time the approval process has ever been used. 
And as I stated, we firmly believe the proposed benefit reduction plan does not comply with the law. We recognized there are a lot of unanswered questions but without Treasury's decision, we are not going to speculate. However, we still thought it was important to provide you an update on the process. 
Now I will turn it over to Richard for a financial view of the issue.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Norm. We estimate that the Central States plan is approved as proposed and implemented, we will be required to record a charge of approximately $3.2 billion to $3.8 billion later this year. Our estimates are based on the information currently avai
componenttext:
Thanks, Norm. We estimate that the Central States plan is approved as proposed and implemented, we will be required to record a charge of approximately $3.2 billion to $3.8 billion later this year. Our estimates are based on the information currently available to UPS, and assumes, among other things, that the plan's implementation is not delayed.
If this charge is necessary, we expect it will be treated as an interim mark-to-market pension charge and will be reflected in this year's financial results. In addition, there may be an increase in the ongoing pension expense that could impact 2016. 
Following our call today, we'll provide a presentation on the website regarding the subject. Now let's move on to business and how it continues to perform.
As David said, the consumer is driving the economy, and that translates into opportunities for UPS. During the quarter, we turned e-commerce growth to expanded margins and increased operating profit in the U.S. Domestic segment. This, combined with momentum in our international business and slightly better than expected performance in supply chain and freight segment, produced another strong quarter. 
Now let's go a little deeper into the results, starting with the U.S. domestic segment, where operating profit increased $78 million or almost 8%, and operating margin expanded 50 basis points to 12.1%.
Revenue was up 3.1% over last year to $9.1 billion. However, lower fuel surcharges were a drag of about 120 basis points on the growth rate. Average daily volume increased 2.8%, with the Ground products up 3.3%, and Next Day Air, up 3%. 
After 5 continuous quarter of double-digit growth, deferred products declined slightly. E-Commerce customers drove both B2C and B2B shipments higher, with B2C up more than 6%. Interestingly, supporting B2B growth during the quarter, online purchases drove demand for UPS's best-in-class return services portfolio, which grew double-digit this quarter.
Base rates increased about 2%, but were offset by changes in package characteristics and a mix of product and customers. There was 120-basis point drag from lower fuel surcharges that weighed on the reported deals. As a result, total revenue per piece was down 1.3% from the prior year. 
This quarter, the margin expansion was driven by the excellent cost management demonstrated. Cost per piece was down 1.9% compared to last year. Network efficiencies continue to improve, and we're seeing those improvements in our bottom line.
At the foundation of our success this quarter is the continued benefits of the UPS integrated network overlaid with our unique technology. Looking at our key daily statistics, and this is where we are seeing good improvement as the expansion of ORION lowered driver miles by about 1%, despite the fact that total stops grew by about 6%. In addition, overall productivity gains helped direct labor hours to an increase of 1.8%, well below the average daily volume growth.
As these trends continue, UPS is improving the stop economics of e-commerce. Now let's turn to the international segment. 
As David said, we are reporting our 5th consecutive quarter of double-digit operating profit growth. International operating profit increased more than 15%, reflecting the impact of discipline pricing, better network efficiencies and in-country cost control.
Revenue on a currency neutral basis was slowed this quarter by management actions we implemented in the third quarter last year. In addition, lower fuel surcharges negatively affected the growth rate by about 200 basis points. Currency neutral revenue per piece was up 1.6%, with domestic products up 2.8%. Strong base rate improvements were across all regions of the world and contributed to the best yield growth in more than 2 years.
Revenue management actions also affected international volume, mainly the non-U.S. domestic products. Meanwhile, we saw increased demand out of Asia and Europe into the U.S, offsetting lower U.S. exports. Export volume has start recovering from the revenue management actions we started in mid-2015. Fewer local operating days, mostly due to the timing of the Easter holiday, lowered the growth rate by about 200 basis points. 
Now let's discuss the Supply Chain & Freight segment, where operating profit was better than anticipated but slightly less than last year. As the segment managed through a tough economic backdrop.
Total revenue on a currency neutral basis was up more than 11%, driven by the addition of Coyote Logistics. The asset-light truckload brokerage business is managing well, even in a market that remains [indiscernible]and in the synergies remain plain. In addition, market conditions remain weak, both in the airfreight 40 [ph] and UPS Freight markets. In the freight 40 unit, international air freight kilos were down and it's due to a combination of repricing efforts in 2015 and an overall softer market. Margins expanded as the unit held firm with rates and achieved higher by sell rate spreads.
Distribution revenue, on a currency neutral basis, was up around 7%. Supported by our industry-specific solutions, we had double-digit gains in health care, aerospace and industrial manufacturing sectors.
UPS Freight remains committed to disciplined revenue management. LTL revenue per hundredweight increased 2.1% as the unit continue  to focus on serving higher-yielding middle market customers, yet total tonnage declined as market conditions remain challenging.
Now for an update in our cash position. The company generated $2.2 billion in free cash flow after investing almost $430 million in capital expenditures. UPS improved its quarterly dividend by almost 7% during the quarter and paid about $670 million in dividends. And the company repurchased 6.8 million shares for approximately $680 million. 
Now I'd like to update you on our guidance for 2016. 
The first quarter results continued our momentum from last year, and we remain on track for 2016. Economic conditions around the world remain mixed. However, our business model is adapting well in this environment. In addition, international and supply chain & freight will lap certain pricing actions we took last year. 
Based on our current performance, we'll reaffirm our 2016 full year guidance of 570 [ph] to 590 [ph] adjusted earnings per share. This guidance does not include any impact for the Department of Treasury's decision on the benefit reduction plan. Regardless of how UPS chooses to respond to Treasury's decision, we still expect to remain within our 2016 guidance. However, if the plan is approved and implemented without delay, the ongoing expense could possibly push us to its lower end of the range.  As we stated earlier, we fully intend to continue challenging the plan if it is approved by the treasury. 
To summarize. This quarter as an example of how our accelerated investments are providing benefits across the company. We are adapting to the changing market conditions, bending the cost curve and at the same time, producing strong financial results. We are well-positioned to continue to make progress through the rest of the 2016. 
And now I'll ask the operator to open the lines for the questions. Operator?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Just want to know your thoughts on yield, just given the competitive as we are seeing in truckload load rates, in particular during 2016 at 2% base rate within domestic, what is the likelihood that, that meets or exceeds that level as we move through 2016?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ben, this is Alan. First of all, we saw some really good volume growth in the U.S. that certainly was milder than our expectations and we continue to align the revenue, the value we create with the cost and curve. The first quarter '16, we certainly conti
componenttext: Ben, this is Alan. First of all, we saw some really good volume growth in the U.S. that certainly was milder than our expectations and we continue to align the revenue, the value we create with the cost and curve. The first quarter '16, we certainly continued our successful base rate strategy and we did achieve a base rate increase between the 2% and 3%. It was offset by about 120 basis points to lower fuel surcharges as well as continue to still see some significant changes in the customer and the product mix and the package characteristics that were also weighing on that base rate increase. Just one quick example here. SurePost, it's the lowest revenue piece product in our portfolio by its nature. It achieved double-digit growth this quarter. It also has some of the highest delivery density in our network and it generates excellent profitability [indiscernible] and it's even more profitable when we combine that with our SurePost Redirect. So we got a lot of examples where we're focusing on driving profits, where the revenue to cost ratio is -- where the RBP is lower than average like STS, UPS Access Point, Returns, they're all significant density creators. Rich, you got some comments?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ben, the other thing that's important to understand is we make the adjustments for how the characteristics are changing, the benefits that we're seeing on how we are handling within our network in the implementation of our technology is showing up in the
componenttext: Ben, the other thing that's important to understand is we make the adjustments for how the characteristics are changing, the benefits that we're seeing on how we are handling within our network in the implementation of our technology is showing up in the bottom line. And as you saw, the cost per piece actually reduced almost 2%, and that created the margin expansion in the U.S.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: If I could just ask to clarify comment there. Is there enough disconnect in terms of the what customer conversations that B2C and e-commerce growth can be viewed separately from their broader kind of freight fundamentals? Specifically, the pricing on the
componenttext: If I could just ask to clarify comment there. Is there enough disconnect in terms of the what customer conversations that B2C and e-commerce growth can be viewed separately from their broader kind of freight fundamentals? Specifically, the pricing on the truck loads as such that you can continue to get positive and healthy yields with regard to B2C in particular, even though broader freight rates in 2016 appear be to be much weaker than that?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think there's definitely 2 distinct markets there. It's certainly a competitive market, but we focus on pricing consistent with the value we provide our customers. And we're continuing to enhance our efficiencies like Richie said and our value propositi
componenttext: I think there's definitely 2 distinct markets there. It's certainly a competitive market, but we focus on pricing consistent with the value we provide our customers. And we're continuing to enhance our efficiencies like Richie said and our value proposition with what David mentioned on UPS Early Express, so on and so forth. So yes, we're confident being able to achieve the range of 2% to 3% going forward.

componenttextpreview: I just want to ask around the international margin improvement. Congratulations on the strong margin improvement there. I was wondering if you could give us the sense of -- I guess the -- you talked about some of the key drivers, but that does the pace of
componenttext: I just want to ask around the international margin improvement. Congratulations on the strong margin improvement there. I was wondering if you could give us the sense of -- I guess the -- you talked about some of the key drivers, but that does the pace of that accelerate? Does it kind of sustain in terms of some of the things that you're doing to drive that 300 -- almost 300 basis points margin? Just so we have way to look at it going forward in the next couple of quarters.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tom, this is Richard. I think the first thing, it was a very strong quarter. But our focus is really on our earnings or growth in earnings and economic value more than in the margin because of the fluctuations in the network and which products are growing
componenttext: Tom, this is Richard. I think the first thing, it was a very strong quarter. But our focus is really on our earnings or growth in earnings and economic value more than in the margin because of the fluctuations in the network and which products are growing stronger year in and year out. The other thing to keep in mind is that the hedge program that we really had in place [indiscernible] does are the margin. Even if you adjust out for that, you're still talking about almost a 17% margin, which is the best in the industry. I'm going to ask Jim to actually comment a few of the initiatives that are driving improvements in the international.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tom, I think it's really a 2-part question for me. One is backward looking, how we've done, we've seen in the last 5 [ph] quarters. We feel good about that. I think the other side to it is that at the same time, right in line with our overall growth strat
componenttext: Tom, I think it's really a 2-part question for me. One is backward looking, how we've done, we've seen in the last 5 [ph] quarters. We feel good about that. I think the other side to it is that at the same time, right in line with our overall growth strategy, we are able to invest in some of the growth platforms we've talked about over the last year, 1.5 years. Like Access Points, like Southern and trade link border across the world and emerging markets. So that ultimately, as you hear it now, you see the margins and you'll hear which is comment with respect to the lift in currencies and so on and so forth. But the general operating efficiency and base rate is holding us but at the same time we feel really good, I do, about the investments we're making for the long-term at the same time. So I appreciate the question.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just maybe a little bit of clarification on the pension exposure you talked about, the opening of the call, the $3.2 billion, the $3.8 billion. Is that a cash -- a onetime charge? Is that a cash expense that you would have to pay out? And then more on the
componenttext: Just maybe a little bit of clarification on the pension exposure you talked about, the opening of the call, the $3.2 billion, the $3.8 billion. Is that a cash -- a onetime charge? Is that a cash expense that you would have to pay out? And then more on the ongoing level, you talked about. Can you talk about the ongoing impact and what the ongoing cost exposure could be? You talked about moving at lower end of the range, but just maybe give us some parameters on what the ongoing expense would be?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So I think the first question you asked was whether it is a onetime payout. And actually, the way -- first of all, it's a complicated topic and there will be a deck I mentioned down on the website to explain a little bit better. But it really isn't
componenttext: Sure. So I think the first question you asked was whether it is a onetime payout. And actually, the way -- first of all, it's a complicated topic and there will be a deck I mentioned down on the website to explain a little bit better. But it really isn't something we're paying to a third-party. It would be a liability that we would have to take on. But that -- in fact, we look at many different scenarios and we feel comfortable that even if this was approved and while we go down the path of looking at our other options legally that it would have a operating income impact but it would still keep us within the range that we gave at the beginning of the year. So there's a lot of unanswered questions that we just don't know until we know more from Treasury's decision, but at this point that's all we can share with you.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And this is David Abney. I just want to remind people that we do not know how Treasury is going to decide. We are expecting a decision between now and May 7, May 8. But they could reject or they could accept. We just felt it was important to get the infor
componenttext: And this is David Abney. I just want to remind people that we do not know how Treasury is going to decide. We are expecting a decision between now and May 7, May 8. But they could reject or they could accept. We just felt it was important to get the information out to just gives you an idea if they did accept the plan. But we really don't have an idea of which way that they're going to decide. So we don't want to send any impression out there.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: David Vernon with Bernstein.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Richard maybe a question for you on the productivity side. It seems like the mix was a little bit weaker in the quarter. I'm just wondering if that's kind of a fair assessment? And then as you think about that decline of 190 [ph] basis points year-over-ye
componenttext: Richard maybe a question for you on the productivity side. It seems like the mix was a little bit weaker in the quarter. I'm just wondering if that's kind of a fair assessment? And then as you think about that decline of 190 [ph] basis points year-over-year in the unit cost for the domestic segment, was that influenced anyway by the mix? Did you get some help there for some of the lighter weight or lower cost products versus kind of pure productivities there? And the way we think about sort of breaking out that 190 [ph] basis points in relation to mix?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Because we want an integrated network, and we think about the activities that occur, mix has a little bit of play when SurePost grows faster. But I would tell you that we expected SurePost to grow faster this year. Last year we talked about SurePost will
componenttext: Because we want an integrated network, and we think about the activities that occur, mix has a little bit of play when SurePost grows faster. But I would tell you that we expected SurePost to grow faster this year. Last year we talked about SurePost will continue to grow. But that being said, when you look specifically at what we're doing in the U.S. with how direct labor hours are being managed because of really the overlay of ORION and what we're able to do with reducing miles at the same time is increasing stops. It's something we're starting to see the last few quarters and in fact we still expect to continue to see in. And actually [indiscernible] going to have talk a little bit some of the initiatives that you've seen from ORION and what's happening in it because the expansion of the margin really was something that we did expect and we continue to expect.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So David, it's really a combination of a number of activities that we're undertaking to continue to bend the cost curve. Richard has referred to ORION, and yes while our stops grew almost 6%, we were able to reduce our mile by 1%. But when you add in Sure
componenttext: So David, it's really a combination of a number of activities that we're undertaking to continue to bend the cost curve. Richard has referred to ORION, and yes while our stops grew almost 6%, we were able to reduce our mile by 1%. But when you add in SurePost Redirect, couple with Access Point, it allows us to build greater densities that we're taking advantage of. You've also heard us talk about SDS. And Edge, which we'll be talking more about later this quarter -- this year. Those activities combined regardless of the mix, has allowed us to continue to bend that cost curve. They do couple that with some of the automation projects that we have in place is not only allowing us to bend the cost curve but also ramping up our service to our customers.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Chris Wetherbee, Citi.
componenttext: Chris Wetherbee, Citi.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wanted to ask about the volume growth, which was impressive in the quarter. We definitely saw re-acceleration. And I think in the comments, you mentioned that the B2B side benefited all the way from e-Commerce returns. Just wanted to get a sense if you co
componenttext: Wanted to ask about the volume growth, which was impressive in the quarter. We definitely saw re-acceleration. And I think in the comments, you mentioned that the B2B side benefited all the way from e-Commerce returns. Just wanted to get a sense if you could parse out maybe how the industrial side of your business is sort of trending? And maybe if you expect that ground growth to continue through the rest of the year here, outside of what we saw from e-Commerce which is probably at least partially holiday-related? Some comments will be helpful.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Chris, this is Alan. As you said we really had a strong quarter of B2C growth, and our customers are really responding to the choices we're providing. The e-Commerce customers drove both B2C and B2B shipments higher, with the B2C up more than 6%. [indisce
componenttext: Chris, this is Alan. As you said we really had a strong quarter of B2C growth, and our customers are really responding to the choices we're providing. The e-Commerce customers drove both B2C and B2B shipments higher, with the B2C up more than 6%. [indiscernible] realized our best B2C growth in the last 5 quarters and like Rich said, we've achieved margin expansion with that growth with B2C. The online purchases are continuing to drive demand for UPS best-in-class services, which are essentially the business delivery and we did see mid-teens return growth there. We think as B2C grows, we're going to see very strong returns growth there, that's going to be help our B2B segment. So overall, B2B still in positive territory impacted by the softness in industrial production, but we've been positive on B2B growth for the last few years now, with the exception of 1 quarter. So -- we -- the economy is certainly soft after when it comes to industrial production, but we think the combination of our B2C and our B2B value proposition to the non-retail segment is going to allow us to continue to grow that B2B business.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nate Brochmann, William Blair.
componenttext: Nate Brochmann, William Blair.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Obviously, this has been well-publicized in terms of a very high profile customer, kind of maybe doing some more things and how [indiscernible] talked about the value proposition for UPS a lot over the years. But have you seen probably the majority of wha
componenttext: Obviously, this has been well-publicized in terms of a very high profile customer, kind of maybe doing some more things and how [indiscernible] talked about the value proposition for UPS a lot over the years. But have you seen probably the majority of what they plan to do already taking in house, in terms of that already kind of being behind you? And has that impacted at all kind of the density benefits that maybe we were on previous trajectory to be able to get and be up to be anything that circumvent that?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nate, this is David. I would just start out by saying that high profile customer, I think because the scale and the scope gets a lot of attention and everything that they do obviously, can appear under the microscope, I can tell you though that we have --
componenttext: Nate, this is David. I would just start out by saying that high profile customer, I think because the scale and the scope gets a lot of attention and everything that they do obviously, can appear under the microscope, I can tell you though that we have -- we value our mutually beneficial relationship. And obviously, we evaluate any market moves than any company, or customer mix, and we look at it from a competitive standpoint. Where I really want to focus is our integrated network creates efficiencies and just gives us a value proposition that is very difficult to match. Our diverse customer base, also just from a density standpoint, no single company is going to be able to match that. So we had value of global scale and scope. We continue to invest in technology to deliver high-value solutions and they are going to be customers that are going to utilize us as a single source. There's also going to be other customers that are going to adjust. And sometimes go single source, sometimes go multiple vendors and sometimes they will bring some work inside take it in-house. And that's going to adjust as conditions adjust. But we feel we have a good relationship with the customer and feel that we will continue to add value for many, many years to come.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will be from the line of Brandon Oglenski of Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question will be from the line of Brandon Oglenski of Barclays.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So can we come back to the economic picture? You guys talked a lot about how you moved 6% of U.S. GDP in your network every day. How do we read the divergent from industrial production and consumer growth plus really weak international trade but you're st
componenttext: So can we come back to the economic picture? You guys talked a lot about how you moved 6% of U.S. GDP in your network every day. How do we read the divergent from industrial production and consumer growth plus really weak international trade but you're still seeing premium expansion in your network? What does this all mean for GDP and IP looking forward? And have your customers given you any view on expectations, heading into the back half of the year on inventories and growth?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, Brandon. It's David. There are customers have given us a lot of views. And I'll give the same impression to that, that I would [indiscernible] is very mixed. And yes, GDP is obviously, weakened even today, the numbers that came out quarter-over-quar
componenttext: Okay, Brandon. It's David. There are customers have given us a lot of views. And I'll give the same impression to that, that I would [indiscernible] is very mixed. And yes, GDP is obviously, weakened even today, the numbers that came out quarter-over-quarter showed weakness and year-over-year, slight deterioration. But again, you can look and you can find bright spots and you can find things that worry  you. On the  one hand consumer spending, continue to be the primary economic driver in the U.S. On the other hand, industrial production has been disappointing. Although I can't say there has been some recent data on manufacturing that are showing some sign of expansion. On the  one hand again, online retail is continuing to grow much faster than many expected. On the other hand, especially brick-and-mortar retailers have not done so well. Again, on one hand, inflation and unemployment have stabilized, although wage growth from courses has been muted. And when you look at it internationally, I think the same thing. You're going to see positives and when you go see things that concern you. From the European Union, we still expect to see that economy grow, at a fairly solid pace compared to recent past. But there are signs of slowing, especially in some countries. Emerging markets, you see some concerns there, especially in Brazil and Russia. China though, GDP forecast is stabilized. If you look at U.S's. exports, because of the strength of the dollar, that, of course, is weakened. But when you look at European exports imported into the U.S., that is -- that has been pretty solid. But my final point, and I think it's what's led to our success the last 4, 5 quarters and will continue to lead to it is that regardless of these challenges, we hope to make challenges opportunities. And that's how we execute our investments, our strategic initiatives. If we continue to execute, we have proven and we will continue to prove that we can have success in this mixed economic environment. So thank you for the question. I appreciate it.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Just one quick question, just coming back to the pension issue for a second. If this thing happens, does it have any impact on capital allocation, share buybacks going forward this year or next year?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The short answer is it doesn't have any impact in 2016. We continue to outweigh [ph] capital the way we planned. For everything for 2016, we continue on the plan. There's a lot of unanswered questions that we talked about, but that won't change what we're
componenttext: The short answer is it doesn't have any impact in 2016. We continue to outweigh [ph] capital the way we planned. For everything for 2016, we continue on the plan. There's a lot of unanswered questions that we talked about, but that won't change what we're doing for this year. And for '17, later in the year when our guys, we'll go through there. As I told you [indiscernible] multiple scenarios, uncertainty will be understood a little differently. And then we'll make the appropriate plans, because there are different things and different tools available to us as well. So I just think it's too early to look at that, but '16 will continue as is.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Our next question will come from the line of Allison Landry, Crédit Suisse.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: In terms of your comments that you're improving the stop economics of B2C, first, can you cover all the impact of productivity gains versus fuel and the 2% improvement? And then curious if the rapid growth in e-commerce is finally, starting to lead the de
componenttext: In terms of your comments that you're improving the stop economics of B2C, first, can you cover all the impact of productivity gains versus fuel and the 2% improvement? And then curious if the rapid growth in e-commerce is finally, starting to lead the density increases in global and regional markets.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Alice, this is Richard. The interesting thing is fuel is lower, it does have an impact on both the top end of revenue, but if you pull those out, we still had negative cost per piece growth. And so we are seeing that the benefits of everything that
componenttext: Sure. Alice, this is Richard. The interesting thing is fuel is lower, it does have an impact on both the top end of revenue, but if you pull those out, we still had negative cost per piece growth. And so we are seeing that the benefits of everything that we've been really building in the last 2 years shown up in the bottom line and we actually talked about the margin expansion and that plan is a multi-year plan. And so that will continue as we expected it to. And that's it. Thank you.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Our next question will come from Jeff Kauffman from Buckingham Research.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Jeff. I just wanted to ask a question about CapEx and free cash flow. I mean there's tremendous free cash generation this first quarter, so congratulations. But you threw out almost $2.6 billion in free cash and I was modeling about $5.5 billion for
componenttext: It's Jeff. I just wanted to ask a question about CapEx and free cash flow. I mean there's tremendous free cash generation this first quarter, so congratulations. But you threw out almost $2.6 billion in free cash and I was modeling about $5.5 billion for the year. Have you changed your capital plan at all? Or is there are a reason free cash might be a little stronger than expected this year obviously, holding off for anything what may or may not happen with this pension situation?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, again this is Richard. When you actually look at our cash position and where we are at as a company, after the first quarter, we're about where we were last year. In fact, our cash is slightly above $100 million less than last year at this point. So
componenttext: Sure, again this is Richard. When you actually look at our cash position and where we are at as a company, after the first quarter, we're about where we were last year. In fact, our cash is slightly above $100 million less than last year at this point. So when we look at our plan, it's about the whole year. And I also want to remind you that a large portion of our cash, about 40%, is offshore. And repatriation with additional tax and we need that money off shore for the investments we're making in Europe and Asia as well. So our plan is built at the beginning of the year and it's something that -- we are working that plan, and the plan really is built to return to shareholders what we've been doing previously. We are investing $2.8 billion in CapEx, and we actually spent about 20% more than the first quarter this year than we did last year. So we'll continue working that plan.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is David. I just want to clarify a little bit, though we are clearly opposing Central State's plan, and that shouldn't indicate any change in our part to our long term capital expenditure plan. So again, this is something that has not happened. We do
componenttext: This is David. I just want to clarify a little bit, though we are clearly opposing Central State's plan, and that shouldn't indicate any change in our part to our long term capital expenditure plan. So again, this is something that has not happened. We don't know if it will or if it won't, I don't want anyone to read into comments that maybe we are adjusting our strategy based on this. We continue to execute this capital plan just as we originally planned. Thank you.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: With one of your competitor's getting ready, to make an -- or hopefully, making an acquisition for them in Europe, have you seen any changes in the marketplace over there? Any customer dislocation, i.e. any risk or opportunities ahead of that?
componenttext: With one of your competitor's getting ready, to make an -- or hopefully, making an acquisition for them in Europe, have you seen any changes in the marketplace over there? Any customer dislocation, i.e. any risk or opportunities ahead of that?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Art, this is David. And in Europe, it does look like that the acquisition is going to be approved. And the things that I wanted to cover on that is that we have a very strong position in Europe. We've been winning in Europe for sometime now and we've cert
componenttext: Art, this is David. And in Europe, it does look like that the acquisition is going to be approved. And the things that I wanted to cover on that is that we have a very strong position in Europe. We've been winning in Europe for sometime now and we've certainly been sprinting over the last several years. We haven't changed our strategy, we're going to continue to invest in growing in Europe and we're certainly seeing the benefits of that in 2015. We're in the beginnings of our 5-year, $2 billion network investment, and we're already seeing benefits from that. And just to give you an idea, you know that Europe is a key part of our strategy and we just had great momentum. We've had 5 consecutive quarters of double-digit operating profit. So what we're hearing from our customers is that we continue to provide value and they continue to give us more of their share of the business. So we think it's a very positive environment for us.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Jim. I think a couple of other points in the back of at which David just mentioned, is that we talked over the last few 1.5 years [ph] about the capital outlay plan of $2 billion. I think it's important to note, especially in line with our top line g
componenttext: It's Jim. I think a couple of other points in the back of at which David just mentioned, is that we talked over the last few 1.5 years [ph] about the capital outlay plan of $2 billion. I think it's important to note, especially in line with our top line growth discussion, is that we've only touched 19 of our planned almost 70 facilities that we plan to expand throughout the network. So we won't be done until 2018. We're going to be doing that much in line with, as you pointed out, what is the customer's expectation in Europe, post merger. We've had our eyes on that for some time obviously, on the road we travel. And so we are kind of looking at our customer solutions specifically, and our network and making sure that it leans into those risks and opportunities and any merger brings for us. So we are looking forward with the years to come in Europe.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Andrew. First, let me start by saying I have mentioned that even adjusting our currency, we are talking about almost a 17% operating margin. So it's a very positive and best of the best margin in the industry. The other big thing to remember is -- a
componenttext: Sure, Andrew. First, let me start by saying I have mentioned that even adjusting our currency, we are talking about almost a 17% operating margin. So it's a very positive and best of the best margin in the industry. The other big thing to remember is -- and we talked about it, I think in my talk a little bit, was just when we look at the yields for international, it was the strongest yield we've seen in quite some time, both in the non-U.S. domestic and in the international exports as well. And your question also mentioned fuel and let me also remind you that we don't use fuel as a profit center. So it doesn't impact the revenue line, but it's really not a big impact to what happens on the bottom line. This quarter is really about great cost control and the quality of revenue. And it's really something that [indiscernible] folks started mid last year, when we took on some revenue management initiatives. And we know we'll wrap that the second half of the year. We guided definitely at the beginning of the year. And so this is really a very valid profit picture and a return for the quarter for international.

componenttext: I know it's only April, but as we look out to 2017, can you remind us of how much of the FX hedge protection that you had in 2015 and '16 is going to roll off next year? Just how should we think about the impact of the losses from those hedges from a sensitivity perspective? [indiscernible] Looking at your international segment margins or maybe an overall EPS impact on the company.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Richard again. The first thing I want to remind everyone is we do use a multiyear hedge strategy, and has worked for well for the last 2 years. And underlying that is really the strength of our business, because the core businesses is running very
componenttext: This is Richard again. The first thing I want to remind everyone is we do use a multiyear hedge strategy, and has worked for well for the last 2 years. And underlying that is really the strength of our business, because the core businesses is running very well. Right now we're in the middle of the process. We continue to look at different opportunities because of the volatility of currency to go in into different hedging to protect and minimize the change. It's really a little too early to talk about what it's going to be because we're still in the middle of that. And then yes, we know that euro went from 135 [ph] down to today's rates but we're also looking at what other initiatives across the entire enterprise we can move forward to offset some of that. So we'll continue to work on those 2 efforts and its appropriate calendar time, we'll update you on '17.

componenttext: I just wanted to follow up on an earlier economic question. Is there any to break down how much you adjusted 7% to 11% EPS growth you're expecting this year? Just to get a sense of maybe how much of the growth story is in your own control, despite what happens in the macro environment.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. When we make our guidance at the beginning of the year [indiscernible] as the year goes, we have a certain assumption. But what's going to happen with economic indicators and they have come down. When you go back to January and you look at what GDP
componenttext: Sure. When we make our guidance at the beginning of the year [indiscernible] as the year goes, we have a certain assumption. But what's going to happen with economic indicators and they have come down. When you go back to January and you look at what GDP is doing and what expectations were around the globe, those have all come down. On the other side, what's happened -- what's happening in the UPS and what we're seeing is that the continued margin expansion, the things that we talked about in both international and domestic around from a cost and network efficiency standpoint as well as making the adjustments as the volume looks different. So today, I'd say it's more about what's happening in UPS, but we also have been continue to think about what have been externally from what does have an impact. But because one is a little bit better, was going to be a good year and the others a little weaker. You put it together, we think where we are in the guidance is the right place.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is David. Just to reinforce, Rich, it's nice to have tailwinds. And obviously, prefer not to have headwinds but that's not the world we live in. What we have been able to do over the past 5 quarters so is to deal with the hands that we have dealt and
componenttext: This is David. Just to reinforce, Rich, it's nice to have tailwinds. And obviously, prefer not to have headwinds but that's not the world we live in. What we have been able to do over the past 5 quarters so is to deal with the hands that we have dealt and make the most of it. And our management team to help grow this focus on absolutely that and most important is that we stay disciplined and focused on our strategic initiatives. As long as we do that, we're going to be in good shape and we're proud with what the team's been able to do. Thank you.

Would seem to be heating up a little bit after about 5 years of discussion and also the clone strike or the pilots didn't fly some planes this week due to their -- some of the strike severity?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, this is Myron. It's not unusual to see some of that recent headlines that have been robust on behalf of the pilots. But let me assure you that there is no real threat of a strike. We remain, along with the pilot's union, at the bargaining table, an
componenttext: David, this is Myron. It's not unusual to see some of that recent headlines that have been robust on behalf of the pilots. But let me assure you that there is no real threat of a strike. We remain, along with the pilot's union, at the bargaining table, and we believe as usual that there will be a win-win negotiation at the end of this for both the pilots and UPS. And also as a reminder, we're at that negotiating table with the National Mediation Board. And it would take action on their behalf to release both bodies an order to have something to happen. And the reality is, that's not going to happen anytime soon. So we're going to get this thing done.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dave, it's Jim. On the Cologne situation just a couple of points I'd like to reinforce. First of all, there's [indiscernible] or a manifestations that they might be called in the world especially in Europe, that we have to deal with, day in, day out in ou
componenttext: Dave, it's Jim. On the Cologne situation just a couple of points I'd like to reinforce. First of all, there's [indiscernible] or a manifestations that they might be called in the world especially in Europe, that we have to deal with, day in, day out in our business. This specific situation, to be very clear, where it stands in Germany and the state of North [indiscernible] Australia was really not even in the logistics sector, it was in the government sector. And that had a whole -- it has a whole another set of what views to it. The IPA and the pilots took their stance on that. Our job is to run the network. And I would tell you over the last 48 hours, the guys have done a heckuva job over there, just like the last time the ash cloud appeared and that powered the ground and the area network came through. And tonight, our network will be just as normal, tonight, Thursday night in Cologne, and we expect to provide great service going forward. So I'll stop on that. I appreciate the question.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: You bought a stake in Berlin [ph] , I think in February of this year. Can you just talk about the rationale behind that? What you've learned so far? And also how you see the omni-channel retail shift as a potential opportunity or threat? Will it just be a
componenttext: You bought a stake in Berlin [ph] , I think in February of this year. Can you just talk about the rationale behind that? What you've learned so far? And also how you see the omni-channel retail shift as a potential opportunity or threat? Will it just be a general disruptor in the e-commerce channel?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Alan. As you guys know, we've been a same-day business for a long time with Express Credit goal and a world-class service force logistics network, but certainly there's a lot of buzz with e-commerce with same day. And the real challenge is obvious
componenttext: This is Alan. As you guys know, we've been a same-day business for a long time with Express Credit goal and a world-class service force logistics network, but certainly there's a lot of buzz with e-commerce with same day. And the real challenge is obviously, low cost e-commerce delivery, because the consumers are looking for a low-cost option there. Currently, as you know, same day for e-commerce has challenges with consolidating density in single piece stop economics that carry profitability issues, as these companies look for the low-cost model. There is goal is pretty unique, It consolidates multiple deliveries on one driver with pick ups for multiple stores at a mall, for example. So we're looking to get some key learnings there. So we made that investment in, to better understand the economics demand and value proposition and certainly we are a leader in that particular space. At the same time, we believe that because the lion share of shopping takes place in the late afternoon and evenings, there is much more demand for local next day, which really speaks to the latter part of your question about omnichannel. And we're very focused on those local store solutions that enable us to take evening orders that are dropped to the stores, let the stores fulfill them locally that same evening over the UPS late-night pickup. We can get next day or morning delivery. So we can make the delivery in as little as 10 to 12 hours from the time the order is dropped and checked out. And you combine that again with our industry-leading e-commerce platform and we're really leading the way in the B2C e-commerce market. Thanks.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Not sure how many employees at UPS are minimum wage employees, but there's just move especially in California to push the minimum wage up. And I'm just kind of wondering how will that affect your compensation, your outlook for keeping costs under control in that line? And any comments you can make will be appreciated.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, this is Richard. And I think the one thing that's important to understand about UPS is that many of our wages are part of our national bargaining agreements. So there are very few employees where the start rate would be something that would be affec
componenttext: Sure, this is Richard. And I think the one thing that's important to understand about UPS is that many of our wages are part of our national bargaining agreements. So there are very few employees where the start rate would be something that would be affected by the minimum wage change. That being said, in some states where there's a slight change it would impact only the people that are first coming onto the parallel with UPS because there's a progression schedule. So it's a very small impact. We've looked at it and I'm talking hundreds of thousands of dollars kind of thing because it's not -- it's just not something -- it's our value proposition as an employer in giving the full benefits and the rates we pay our things that are going to drive additional costs forward as sort of in any meaningful way.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: We have a question from the line of Rob Salmon of Deutsche Bank.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Piggybacking on the e-commerce question which have come up, basically 2-ply for me from Robbie. If I think about the local delivery opportunity from a UPS perspective, historically, I've always thought of that as a tougher market to compete in, particular
componenttext: Piggybacking on the e-commerce question which have come up, basically 2-ply for me from Robbie. If I think about the local delivery opportunity from a UPS perspective, historically, I've always thought of that as a tougher market to compete in, particularly when there's some crowdsourcing opportunities given your cost structure. Could you talk a little bit about the attractiveness or not of that marketplace from your perspective? And more broadly, what are the markets you think make the most sense to attack from an e-commerce perspective, given your returns and margin profile?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Alan. Thanks for the question. Look, it's really about the whole e-commerce platform in UPS. But certainly, all of our brick-and-mortar retailers are also in the e-commerce business. So it's about providing them a total solution. And omnichannel i
componenttext: This is Alan. Thanks for the question. Look, it's really about the whole e-commerce platform in UPS. But certainly, all of our brick-and-mortar retailers are also in the e-commerce business. So it's about providing them a total solution. And omnichannel is a growing trend in the retail industry. We're seeing 30% year-over-year growth in UPS accounts in 2015, and that means at the store level, we've got over 120,000 ship-from-store locations that are shipping or have the potential to ship. We're starting to see this phenomenal start to take place also outside the U.S. and our international business. So we think it's a real advantage for the retailers to optimize for a number of things. Sometimes it's inventory saving the order, because the order is not in the e-commerce fulfillment center but it's in the store. Other times, it's to speed up the delivery. Other times, it's to get to the lowest cost option. So it's really about the whole platform that we offer with UPS My Choice, UPS Access Point, the omnichannel, the SurePost, Returns, the marketplace tools we provide, so on and so forth that we're out there selling along with obviously, the power of our whole product portfolio aligned to the integrated network that's really driving that success. And I guess last thing I'd say is that one of the questions earlier were about the density creation. Where we're really creating this density synthetically through all those e-commerce solutions that I just spoke of because all of them both drive customer and consumer convenience as well as density for UPS. And you combine that with some of the things that we're doing on the efficiency side with ORION and automation and things that Myron talked about, we really believe we've got a great platform for e-commerce for both retailers, consumers and to continue to enhance UPS profitability.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. This is David. Just like to review quickly. UPS had another excellent first quarter. We are very effectively implementing our strategic initiatives, and we are investing in new capabilities in the right places, which will ensure that we remain the w
componenttext: Okay. This is David. Just like to review quickly. UPS had another excellent first quarter. We are very effectively implementing our strategic initiatives, and we are investing in new capabilities in the right places, which will ensure that we remain the world's premier logistics provider. Lastly, I would like to make an announcement that would be interesting to me and the people in this call. Joe Wilkins will move into the role of Vice President and Corporate Controller, and Scott will replace Joe as the Vice President and Investor Relations Officer. I'll speak for myself and the company. We are very fortunate to have 2 very extraordinary, qualified and seasoned professionals and I'm confident that each of them will be just as successful in their new roles as they have been in their prior roles. So really, I would like to congratulate Joe and Scott. Appreciate what you guys have done and I'd like to thank everyone on the call for joining us today. Take care.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
