headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe I'll just help on domestic, Richard. I guess the step below sort of long-term guidance growth in that domestic segment, obviously, going down this quarter to 3%. And then an expectation for flat in 3Q. Maybe just think over the next couple 1, 2, 3 y
componenttext: Maybe I'll just help on domestic, Richard. I guess the step below sort of long-term guidance growth in that domestic segment, obviously, going down this quarter to 3%. And then an expectation for flat in 3Q. Maybe just think over the next couple 1, 2, 3 years and that rate of margin change, how should we be expecting sort of that to happen to get to that longer term 15%? And what do you think is going to be different about sort of next year and the year after that wouldn't let you get back to that kind of 8% growth that you guys had put out for the longer target in domestic?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: First, if we step back, if you recall, when we guided this year, and what we've seen through the year is we have seen some softness in macro measures. Everything has kind of come down each quarter this year. And so we take that into account, obviously, wi
componenttext: First, if we step back, if you recall, when we guided this year, and what we've seen through the year is we have seen some softness in macro measures. Everything has kind of come down each quarter this year. And so we take that into account, obviously, with how we think about this year. The good part about this year, even without softness, we are putting initiatives and investments and then bring in returns, that's why were able to be lower guidance right where we expected to be at the first part of the year. That being said, we are in multiyear process of investments both in the ORION that David talked about in his talk, as well as the hub automation and how that will continue. So all of those things are about putting together the multiyear process over were going to improve the margin that we laid out really at the end of '14, we're putting those investments in, those investments are we expected and we just expect as we get more of that in a great tour network we continue to seek the benefits of that. So we feel very comfortable where we're at. We know where on the -- our roadmap for the next few years and we're following that roadmap.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: This David. We're going to take an online question. This one is from Nate Broadman. And as a large e-commerce shipper takes its more, delivery within the denser cities, does that change the density equation at all? And the need retrofit, all of the regi
componenttext:
This David. We're going to take an online question. This one is from Nate Broadman. 
And as a large e-commerce shipper takes its more, delivery within the denser cities, does that change the density equation at all? And the need retrofit, all of the regional sort facilities? And how is that project progressing and what have you learned thus, far in terms of benefits heading into another peak?
So Nate, [indiscernible] for that question. And I will start and address the first part of it and then we'll turn it over to Myron to talk to a bit about the retrofit and peak. It's not unusual and if our large shippers to make position, whether they're going to outsource or insource different parts of their business. Our focus is our diverse customer base, just makes its difficult for anyone company to be able to much lower density no matter their size. So with our integrated network, it creates efficiencies. We're constantly increasing our value proposition. So we always believe that even a large customers would have more density with us then going in another direction. So a very confident in our strategy for that regard. Why don't you talk about the retrofit and peak preparation, Myron?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Nate, the process itself is going well, and we continue to realize 20% to 25% productivity improvements as we go along. Keep in mind, this is a multiyear, multi-phase implementation. And you've heard about some of the cities that we introduced earlier,
componenttext: So Nate, the process itself is going well, and we continue to realize 20% to 25% productivity improvements as we go along. Keep in mind, this is a multiyear, multi-phase implementation. And you've heard about some of the cities that we introduced earlier, in Richard's comments. Our goal is to automate the top Tier 1 hubs, and there's approximately 30 of them in the U.S. That process is much as 60% of our volume. 3 of those automated hosts are in our air operation and the remainder will be in the ground. All new hubs moving forward will be built using an automated design and the second phase of it will be to go to the Tier 2 hubs and automate them as well. So we feel very good about the progress that's being made, and we are on plan and the goal is to get it completed, no later than 2020.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from the line of Mr. Tom Wadewitz of UBS.
componenttext: Our next question will come from the line of Mr. Tom Wadewitz of UBS.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask a bit and specific about ORION. I know Richard, you offered some comments on kind of the high-level multiyear productivity and so forth. But is there -- is 2017 or are you starting to see this year where there's the reduction in the rollou
componenttext: I wanted to ask a bit and specific about ORION. I know Richard, you offered some comments on kind of the high-level multiyear productivity and so forth. But is there -- is 2017 or are you starting to see this year where there's the reduction in the rollout costs and really getting some of the cost savings coming in, in a bigger way? Is -- are you starting to see that? Or is that something which would be maybe a bigger support for domestic margin performance in 2017? And then, you've mentioned at Phase II, I don't know if you want to comment on that. I know that's a couple of questions, maybe just some perspective, a little more detail on ORION.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Tom. What I'll do is I'll start off, and then I'll hand it off to Myron to talk specifically, about the benefits you've seen. But when you think about the investment and what we've been on the road talking about ORION, we have talked about that late
componenttext: Sure, Tom. What I'll do is I'll start off, and then I'll hand it off to Myron to talk specifically, about the benefits you've seen. But when you think about the investment and what we've been on the road talking about ORION, we have talked about that later this year, we'll complete, call it, the first phase of ORION. And then we are investing dollars in call it, Phases 2, and 3 and 4, but on top of that, it's not just the investment in ORION, it's also the investment in hub automation and what that does to the network. So we are using those investment dollars and call it, the additional expense that we were using to train up for ORION in other ways so that we get the end result. And that's kind of what we talked about at the end of '14, and we continue to talk about each year. We are investing in our network, and it's bowling through when you see the reduction in miles and things like that. But the next phase is additional capabilities that will save money and then additional features by having the hub much and do some other things that were working on as well just a little too early to go into. With that, I'm going to send it to my rent to talk on us a little bit about what you've seen operationally with the results of ORION.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tom, let me start with we expect to be 100% fully deployed by the end of 2016 with ORION. And we will continue to see the benefits that we have alluded to earlier, more than 8 miles per driver in savings. For example, this quarter, we saw our deliver stop
componenttext: Tom, let me start with we expect to be 100% fully deployed by the end of 2016 with ORION. And we will continue to see the benefits that we have alluded to earlier, more than 8 miles per driver in savings. For example, this quarter, we saw our deliver stops grow more than 3% on 2.5% average daily volume gains. However, we were able to reduce our miles driven by 0.03%, which help keep our costs per piece, down by 0.02%. So as the volume continues to grow, our weight is growing at the lesser pace than the volume. So we are continuing to see benefits. And that's Phase 1. Phase 2 will actually begin in the back half of this year, well in the 2017 and we hope to have this Phase II completed by 2017, what we hope to see additional benefits from ORION. And again, that's just one of many technology projects that we'll continue to roll out that should help us continue to bend the cost curves. So we're really pleased with what we are seeing.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from the line of Mr. Scott Group of Wolfe Research.
componenttext: Our next question will come from the line of Mr. Scott Group of Wolfe Research.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Actually, just wanted to follow up on the ORION question. So understand that the savings but there's probably some and plantation costs. When you quantify what the implementation cause our this year and if ORION has been a net positive or tailwind to earn
componenttext: Actually, just wanted to follow up on the ORION question. So understand that the savings but there's probably some and plantation costs. When you quantify what the implementation cause our this year and if ORION has been a net positive or tailwind to earnings this year and do you think that next year -- how do you think about next year given the savings from Phase I, but maybe the costs from Phase II? Any color in there would be helpful.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, this is Richard. Yes we are seeing the savings and if you step back a moment and look year-over-year, we continue to see the margin expansion. The margin expansion is a direct result of all the things Myron just talked about. We'll continue to see
componenttext: Again, this is Richard. Yes we are seeing the savings and if you step back a moment and look year-over-year, we continue to see the margin expansion. The margin expansion is a direct result of all the things Myron just talked about. We'll continue to see those improvements and it is a net positive, but we also are spending some of the savings in order to invest in the next phase in the next capability. And those are all important pieces, and that's why -- my comment a few minutes ago about the margin will improve year-over-year, it won't always be linear by quarter. And so that's an important part, because we are investing for new capabilities and to continue to bend the cost curve, because of the investment we are making and the plans we have for the next few years.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is David. Just want to stress that ORION is one of these things -- it's the gift that gives on giving. So what we have seen with ORION is we are seeing benefits that are greater than what we originally believe. And that continues to reinforce itself
componenttext: This is David. Just want to stress that ORION is one of these things -- it's the gift that gives on giving. So what we have seen with ORION is we are seeing benefits that are greater than what we originally believe. And that continues to reinforce itself every year. We have a lot more we're going to accomplish through ORION with the later versions, and taking into various countries. So we are very positive about ORION and about the returns that we are getting. And then we are making are certainly worth it. All right. Net next question would be fine.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question will come from the line of Brandon Oglenski of Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Next question will come from the line of Brandon Oglenski of Barclays Capital.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: As we look out -- can you talk about where to pricing is falling in the U.S. Domestic Package? And why, with this tremendous growth in B2C, that we're not seeing a little bit much traction on yields, which I think, could also talk to this part -- or is th
componenttext: As we look out -- can you talk about where to pricing is falling in the U.S. Domestic Package? And why, with this tremendous growth in B2C, that we're not seeing a little bit much traction on yields, which I think, could also talk to this part -- or is this discussion on domestic margins? Because obviously, we talked a lot about cost, but what are we doing on the revenue side? And is there ability to take more price?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brandon, this is Alan. So for the quarter, we achieved our 2% to 3% range in our base pricing and the core pricing actually remains firm. We actually saw a bit of a bit of an acceleration from the first quarter. Keep in mind that some of the other phenome
componenttext: Brandon, this is Alan. So for the quarter, we achieved our 2% to 3% range in our base pricing and the core pricing actually remains firm. We actually saw a bit of a bit of an acceleration from the first quarter. Keep in mind that some of the other phenomena we are seeing out there is the offset of about 100 basis points due to lower fuel surcharges, and we're going to see changes in the customers and product mix and specifically, the pack -- cat package characteristics as we bring more light weight into the business. The other thing I would say is that we saw -- even with some of those packaged corrector sticks and customer part makes challenge is, we did see margin improvement overall in the U.S. Domestic business. So we think the base rate improvements remains steady, they will continue to remain that way and the core pricing right now is firm.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question will come from the line of Scott Schneeberger with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: Next question will come from the line of Scott Schneeberger with Oppenheimer.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just curious here at the midpoint of the year, obviously, reiterating the guidance range. I'm curious looking at over the second half, what do you view as the swing factor that would put you toward a high end of the low end of the range?
componenttext: Just curious here at the midpoint of the year, obviously, reiterating the guidance range. I'm curious looking at over the second half, what do you view as the swing factor that would put you toward a high end of the low end of the range?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Scott. This is Richard. I think, when you start and when you look at where we're at, year-to-date, first of all in earnings per share, we're at about 8.5% growth in earnings per share on a full -- on a target of 5% to 9%. So we are pleased with wher
componenttext: Sure, Scott. This is Richard. I think, when you start and when you look at where we're at, year-to-date, first of all in earnings per share, we're at about 8.5% growth in earnings per share on a full -- on a target of 5% to 9%. So we are pleased with where we are for the first half of the year. We're actually right in line with where we expected to be. But when we look a guidance, there's really two factors we're looking at. The first is the external and what's happening on the external measures, because that  our volume does have some correlation, especially when you get to B2B to what's happening with both the domestic GDP, things like industrial production and things like that. Mails have soften somewhat from first quarter to second quarter. The other side of it course, is what's happening internally, the things Myron has talked about in his operation. And those improvements that we are seeing. So we put all that together, and we say do we have economic assumptions realistic? And then how we are benefiting from the initiatives that we've implemented. And so we think we bounced all that and that's what we're seeing in 2016. We are seeing a nice balance, where we're making up for some softness that externally with what we're doing internally and that's allowed us to grow our earnings per share for 6 quarters in a row, and we'll continue to work those plans for guidance going forward.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just to Richard's answer, it's our investments and strategies that have allowed us to offset some of this economic shift that we've seen in the last 1.5 years. And we're very comfortable about her our strategic initiatives. We are extremely focused on
componenttext:
So just to Richard's answer, it's our investments and strategies that have allowed us to offset some of this economic shift that we've seen in the last 1.5 years. And we're very comfortable about her our strategic initiatives. We are extremely focused on -- and it's allowing us to overcome some of those headwinds. We'll take the next question. We're doing an online question. This is from Helane Becker. 
And it's are you seeing any signs of weakness in the U.K. related to anything, including Brexit? Jim?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So David, thanks for that one, and Helane as well. I get this question everyday quite frankly, over the last couple of months. But I think, to give a little bit of back drop, when I go back and just remind you of something here. Back in 2008, when we boug
componenttext: So David, thanks for that one, and Helane as well. I get this question everyday quite frankly, over the last couple of months. But I think, to give a little bit of back drop, when I go back and just remind you of something here. Back in 2008, when we bought Links, it was our choice in the U.K. to strengthen that market. To feed the network, we talked about a lot and obviously also feed that country and the consumers. It took us a couple of years to get it done. We're done in 2010. And although we don't talk much about country level performance, I think, this question will give us pretty close to it. I could just tell you that from the years 2010 through '15, that U.K. operation for us, is best-in-class in many ways that we measure our business. So that acquisition and integration that took us about 3 years, has paid dividends for many, many, many years now. Brexit, we don't see changing that for that market quite frankly. Our job is to continue the priority number one, to take care of that economy and the consumers. Our employees and the shareholders and link it into that European network. So that's priority one. The issue obviously becomes what this pretrade agreement's set up to be. Don't forget a couple of things, I think, for my perspective. One, is there are many -- there is a number of free-trade agreements in that union as well. You've got the Norway model, you got the Swiss model and then you've got the EU model. So how it would unfold, we will see, but there are various models that could unfold. We've analyzed scenarios as far left as the WTO set up, all the way back to something close to what they have today. In the end, I think, our priority is to advise and advocate and support consumers as the free trade agreements are finalized in the coming years. And then, continue to whatever happened, support that market and the network and I think, we could easily say that we there will be somewhat more complexity but I think, our job is to simplify the complex in the network for consumers and continue the great service, and that's what we plan to do as that plan unfolds.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from the line of Ben Hartford of Baird.
componenttext: Our next question will come from the line of Ben Hartford of Baird.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wondering what your point of view is today on the acquisition environment, as you start to lap the Coyote acquisition? Obviously, you're taking into account what you said historically about acquisition criteria. Are there specific segments or vertica
componenttext: Just wondering what your point of view is today on the acquisition environment, as you start to lap the Coyote acquisition? Obviously, you're taking into account what you said historically about acquisition criteria. Are there specific segments or verticals that you're more interested in? And then I guess I'm leaving into UPS Freight in particular, giving some of the softness that we've seen, that LTL market. Do you think that, that business is sufficient scale today? Or other potential acquisition opportunities in that segment, specifically?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, Ben. This is David. And I'll answer the first part and then you talked a little bit about Coyote so I'll ask Alan to briefly hit that, and then, the LTL environment and Myron will take that. But from an acquisition standpoint, we have an active proc
componenttext: Okay, Ben. This is David. And I'll answer the first part and then you talked a little bit about Coyote so I'll ask Alan to briefly hit that, and then, the LTL environment and Myron will take that. But from an acquisition standpoint, we have an active process. And we're really looking in what I'll call just 3 general buckets that we're always taking a look at. First is new opportunities. New opportunities that would help us to add more value to our customers. And then, any time that we can expand capability, them up within our network set, so it something that we don't feel strong about this would like to then -- would be that second great tier. And then, third, in all the trade lanes are shifting throughout the world, and so geographic presence is always important. Over the last few years, the emerging markets has been a place that put a lot of attention. So adjacent markets, which is what we did with the coyote acquisition is keen on the mind, but then today, whether it's organic growth or inorganic growth, our focus is on growing this business, and at the same time, having profitable returns. So from a Coyote standpoint, Alan?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, just a quick update on Coyote. Certainly, their customers and our customers and new customers are responding very well to the new Coyote and UPS combined value prop. Now for the quarter, we continued to see strong year-over-year growth in loads. And
componenttext: Yes, just a quick update on Coyote. Certainly, their customers and our customers and new customers are responding very well to the new Coyote and UPS combined value prop. Now for the quarter, we continued to see strong year-over-year growth in loads. And our gross margin is also expanded for the quarter. As I think, we all know, the truckload market remained soft, but certainly, this asset like model has provided some great flexibility in the up-and-down cycles. And then just lastly, I'll just say that as far as the synergies related to the acquisition, we were seeing some good work happening there, in procurement asset utilization, cross-selling and then organizational synergies that are benefiting both Coyote and also U.S. domestic and Supply Chain Freight segments, and we're on track. And now I guess, I'll turn it over to Myron to talk a little bit about the LTL.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ben, as you are well aware, the LTL market for the last 16 consecutive months has experienced softness. And our customer base is telling us that they have high inventory levels. And then in addition to that, with high inventory levels, the opportunity for
componenttext: Ben, as you are well aware, the LTL market for the last 16 consecutive months has experienced softness. And our customer base is telling us that they have high inventory levels. And then in addition to that, with high inventory levels, the opportunity for restocking is soft as well. All postings considered, we believe that we have the appropriate scale at UPS freight. We will have our continue to mark -- monitor the market and make the appropriate adjustments and make the right business decisions moving forward in terms of whether or not to expand our scale.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question will come from the line of Allison Landry of Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: The next question will come from the line of Allison Landry of Crédit Suisse.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could you speak a little bit more to your earlier comments about you as consumer interests and I'll turn it liberty message? I wanted to understand how well penetrated it is even in the urban areas and specifically, how much you think it would be to incre
componenttext: Could you speak a little bit more to your earlier comments about you as consumer interests and I'll turn it liberty message? I wanted to understand how well penetrated it is even in the urban areas and specifically, how much you think it would be to increase from here in order to move the needle on density?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Allison, this is Alan. There's a number of things first of all, that we are doing to improve density, and it's really part of the whole e-commerce value proposition in ecosystem that we put in place. The UPS Access Points, UPS My Choice, the Synchronized
componenttext: Allison, this is Alan. There's a number of things first of all, that we are doing to improve density, and it's really part of the whole e-commerce value proposition in ecosystem that we put in place. The UPS Access Points, UPS My Choice, the Synchronized Delivery Solutions, and certainly Sure Post Redirect, which is now at about the 30% of those packages are being redirected back into the ground network. On access points, right now, we'll probably finish the year at about 27,000 access points, globally. And we continue to expand there. So yes, when you think about bending the cost curve, I guess, 1/10 contributes to about $200 million in bottom line costs, if we -- when we increase the density by 1/10. And then I guess the last thing I'd say is that we continue to be bullish about access points, and we're expanding the current model and then as you probably saw, we invested in our locker expansion after some tests we ran last year, we're laying in 300 lockers into the United States in the -- your point about urban America and urban anywhere in the world, lots of consumers out there that have challenges receiving packages at home in urban areas and the access points and the lockers is a great resolution for them and it also benefits UPS.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from the line of David Ross of Stifel.
componenttext: Our next question will come from the line of David Ross of Stifel.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: You've talked a lot about the U.S. and also about Europe, can you talk a little bit more about Asia and the rest of the world? Which you're seeing going on in there from a trade perspective?
componenttext: You've talked a lot about the U.S. and also about Europe, can you talk a little bit more about Asia and the rest of the world? Which you're seeing going on in there from a trade perspective?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: David , this is Jim. Certainly, the Asia market get also continues to change. Obviously, the biggest market other from a China perspective. We're currently, quite correctly, are seeing very, very nice and actually, momentum picking up in our middle market
componenttext: David , this is Jim. Certainly, the Asia market get also continues to change. Obviously, the biggest market other from a China perspective. We're currently, quite correctly, are seeing very, very nice and actually, momentum picking up in our middle market growth based upon the solution we're providing to the Chinese consumer as their mortal chess is the same time. Certainly, the network that we have in place has served us well for many years this quarter. Overall, I think, the block hours were down about 0.5%. You saw in the early opening comments to the call this morning and the releases that the export volume continues to grow at UPS, and that includes our Asia-Pacific region as well as our Latin America region at the same time. So we continue on one of our big focus is out there is our intra-Asia network. It's a great opportunity for us. We've laid that in, in 2010. We think it has lots more upside. We'll continue to do that, and really, align that as well to the emerging markets strategy that David just referenced a minute ago that we continue to invest in. And I'm confident we'll be referencing on the calls to come. So I appreciate the question.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from the line of Jack Atkins of Stephens.
componenttext: Our next question will come from the line of Jack Atkins of Stephens.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I was wondering if you can expand for a moment on your comments around B2B trends? You referenced in the press release that B2C grew 5x that of B2B, because you may be comment exactly certain what the growth rate was for B2B in the quarter? What portio
componenttext: So I was wondering if you can expand for a moment on your comments around B2B trends? You referenced in the press release that B2C grew 5x that of B2B, because you may be comment exactly certain what the growth rate was for B2B in the quarter? What portion of your U.S. Domestic Package business B2B makes up now? And sort of what customer verticals are you seeing strength or weakness on the B2B side?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Alan. I'll take that question. On the commercial B2B side, we did see a slight increase. The good news is we've seen a slight increase, the last few quarters, there. It's mainly being driven actually by the retail sector and returns. But we are se
componenttext: This is Alan. I'll take that question. On the commercial B2B side, we did see a slight increase. The good news is we've seen a slight increase, the last few quarters, there. It's mainly being driven actually by the retail sector and returns. But we are seeing some growth in some other areas, wholesale, health care and professional services are some of the areas and also consumer and home goods. As you know, industrial production is, as David indicated, was pretty soft and the B2B is really being driven now by retail and some of those other sectors that I've spoken about. I think, our investments really in some of these sectors including Hooker, in helping us to gain share in that particular area. So kind of outrun the economic challenges. And then lastly, our B2C business is about 45% of our business today.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. The next question will come from online. And the question is and this was from the buy side. Do you see any long term opportunities to expand streamline delivery routes with the ride sharing programs? So Alan?
componenttext:
Okay. The next question will come from online. And the question is and this was from the buy side. 
Do you see any long term opportunities to expand streamline delivery routes with the ride sharing programs? So Alan?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, everyone knows on the call that we made a strategic enterprise funded investment a few quarters back in the company named Delive [ph] , which is a retail to consumer same-day B2C delivery company that actually uses the excess capacity out there o
componenttext: I think, everyone knows on the call that we made a strategic enterprise funded investment a few quarters back in the company named Delive [ph] , which is a retail to consumer same-day B2C delivery company that actually uses the excess capacity out there on the market, with people that have vehicle that want to participate in that program. Similar to what's happening on the ride sharing part of the economy there. So they are a leader in this new space. And we're excited to learn more from that. The other thing I would say is that Coyote is really a technology platform that's doing the same thing. It's matching up excess capacity in the marketplace from thousands upon thousands of carriers that have a backhaul excess capacity. And we're providing a similar service with Coyote. So we are excited about that in the heavier truckload type of business as well as for the prospects of potentially on the pickup and delivery side.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from the line of Kelly Dougherty of Macquarie.
componenttext: Our next question will come from the line of Kelly Dougherty of Macquarie.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to think about the U.S. domestic volume growth. Obviously, things like prime are driving demand from more premium products, but I got to get some insight on other retailers are pursuing e-commerce if they're offering free shipping on some all
componenttext: Just wanted to think about the U.S. domestic volume growth. Obviously, things like prime are driving demand from more premium products, but I got to get some insight on other retailers are pursuing e-commerce if they're offering free shipping on some all spending levels. Do you expect that it will show up more in your deferred offerings though that to be the case this quarter? To try to get a sense of what you think the volume and maybe the revenue mix will be at e-commerce growth?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Alan. A couple of points on your question. First, the holiday offerings here in July were pretty widespread amongst our whole number of retailers. I think, we'll see more and more that certainly in the summertime fame, but also in other parts of t
componenttext: This is Alan. A couple of points on your question. First, the holiday offerings here in July were pretty widespread amongst our whole number of retailers. I think, we'll see more and more that certainly in the summertime fame, but also in other parts of the year to drive growth in the e-commerce sector for these retailers, which is critically important for them. Certainly, the e-commerce growth drives significant growth in our ground business and our SurePost business, and then on the overnight and deferred side, mainly in the Saver and the Second Day Air business, but the key here is that we've got this great portfolio, so when the customer absolutely has to have it, they usually are willing to pay for that, and we have the full gamut of services to get those goods to them when they want it. And then we have the more economical alternatives along with some of the other value adds like UPS Access Point, UPS My Choice and omnichannel that really drive those retailers and those consumers to UPS.

componenttext: Yes, this is Alan. I'll take that. First, our premium Next Day Air products grew at nearly 6%, the ground was up more than 2%. So certainly our customers are responding to the continual expansion of our Next Day Air. Our Next Day Air is to serve most postal codes. In fact, all of our Next Day Air services experienced growth. On the other hand, saver, ground and sure post and certainly deferred are focused more on the e-commerce and retail customers. And so on the deferred side, you really need to look at it on a 2-year stack basis. We almost grew 15%, following strong double-digit growth in 2015.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Ravi, this is Richard. And I'll start with the first question on the guidance for '17. And I think, the important thing is we have said that as we move forward, we have continued initiatives that will continue to improve the operating margin. That bein
componenttext: So Ravi, this is Richard. And I'll start with the first question on the guidance for '17. And I think, the important thing is we have said that as we move forward, we have continued initiatives that will continue to improve the operating margin. That being said, obviously, different segments, things will happen and growth rates might have to be adjusted. It's a little early to talk about exactly what's going to happen, and that's really because there's a lot of things going on in volatility of currency too. So the year is, here we are in end of July, we have time still and if you tell me where in November the dollar or euro is or the sterling dollar, that will be a lot about the story of how much variation, that's why we say the plus or minus numbers. The important thing is that we have a plan, it will improve by segment. Our first priority is to reinvest in this business, because of the strength of the company. We continue to deliver the highest row we can the highest margin in the business. And our plan is to continue to do that. And we will continue to do that, while at the same time having dividends of over 3% or around 3%. So as we get closer to the 2017, I'll guide you appropriately. But we are in the middle of putting all of those plan together. And then your second question around the percentage of our share of anyone customer. It's something that we obviously, continue to win customers based on our strategy. To win customers, we don't comment any one customer but you can see our volume growth for the U.S. was up about 2.5%. You just -- for fuel, we saw revenue growth of about 3.4%. So it was a strong quarter. We laid out for you how we think the fourth quarter is going to look, and that's another strong quarter. And we're going to end up delivering on the guidance numbers that we gave you at the beginning of the year. And I think, that's the most important thing.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

componenttext:
We have one last question and this is an online question from Tyler Brown. And it's about return logistics, reverse logistics and kind of two part.
Could you talk about what kind of growth rates you're seeing in return volumes? And talk a little bit about our capabilities on this front? And do we need to do something to add capabilities? So, Alan if you'd take that?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tyler, yes as we said earlier, returns growth has been strong. It's in the midteens. And as you all know, returns is very good business for us because customers tend to drop of those packages off, so we have high density pickup said those type of location
componenttext: Tyler, yes as we said earlier, returns growth has been strong. It's in the midteens. And as you all know, returns is very good business for us because customers tend to drop of those packages off, so we have high density pickup said those type of locations and then high density delivers back to the retailers. UPS has some of the most technology advanced transportation return services, with things like returns on the web, RS 1, RS 3, print label return. So when it comes to label generation, shipping, tracking, visibility, enabling speed and refunds for the consumers, for customer experience, we've got some of the best returns solutions in the business. Combine that with the UPS stores, the UPS Access Points, the lockers, the other alliance partners, UPS drop boxes, there are millions of packages being returned or being delivered to those drop off locations, casting that wide net. And again, I just tie that back to the whole e-commerce ecosystem that we have, that really benefits retailers and consumers and makes UPS the e-commerce transportation company of choice.

componenttext:
Okay. So UPS performed well in the second quarter. We expanded our margins in our international and in our domestic small package business. And very importantly, we are investing today to ensure our performance. So we are at the halfway point of the year. So to UPS's system, this is halftime. And we've had a good first half. We were on plan. But it's very important that we're all committed to our plans and confident in our 2016 guidance. 
So on behalf of the 435,000 UPSers around the world, thank you for your time today. And for all of you, thank you for investing in UPS. Thank you very much.

componenttext: Good morning. My name is Stephen, and I will be your conference facilitator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the UPS Investor Relations Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to turn the floor over to your host, Mr. Scott Childress, Investor Relations Officer. Sir, the floor is yours.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the UPS Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. Joining me today are David Abney, our CEO; Richard Peretz, our CFO; along with International President, Jim Barber; President of U.S. Operations, Myron Gray; and Chief Commercial Offi
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the UPS Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. Joining me today are David Abney, our CEO; Richard Peretz, our CFO; along with International President, Jim Barber; President of U.S. Operations, Myron Gray; and Chief Commercial Officer, Alan Gershenhorn.
Before we begin, I want to review the safe harbor language. Some of the comments we'll make today are forward-looking statements that address our expectations for the future performance or results of operations of our company. These statements are subject to risks and uncertainties, which are described in detail in our 2015 Form 10-K. This report is available on the UPS Investor Relations website and from the Securities and Exchange Commission.
The webcast of today's call, along with the reconciliation of non-GAAP financial measures, are available on the UPS Investor Relations website. Webcast users can submit live questions during today's call. We will attempt to answer questions of a long-term strategic nature. [Operator Instructions]
Thanks for your cooperation. Now I will turn the call over to David.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Scott, and good morning, everyone. I'm pleased to report another quarter of strong financial results that demonstrate the power of UPS's diversified business model. Again, this quarter, the International segment led the way. This is the sixth cons
componenttext:
Thanks, Scott, and good morning, everyone. I'm pleased to report another quarter of strong financial results that demonstrate the power of UPS's diversified business model. Again, this quarter, the International segment led the way. This is the sixth consecutive quarter of double-digit operating profit growth. The U.S. domestic business is growing operating profit on higher B2C demand. Supply chain and freight continued to execute in a challenging macro environment.
Turning to the economy, the consumer market in the U.S. remains healthy and e-commerce forecast have been elevated for 2016, and we are seeing that growth. On the other hand, our B2B volume is affected by the continuing weakness in industrial production. In fact, global GDP and industrial production growth forecast have been downgraded slightly. Delay in the drawdowns and soft export demand likely will remain headwinds in the latter part of 2016. Additionally, we are mindful of the current political commentary on trade.
Increased trade not only bolsters business but also produces jobs here in the U.S. and abroad. Historically, following ratification of trade deals, we have seen about a 20% increase in U.S. exports to the countries involved. UPS is a steadfast proponent of trade and supports agreements that minimize friction in the global supply chain. Trade legislation to accelerate economic expansion, like the Trans-Pacific Partnership, is vital to the health of the U.S. economy. We encourage our political leaders to support and pass pending trade legislation.
Turning to our business. The strategic initiatives implemented over the last 2 years are ensuring we remain on track to achieve our long-term financial goals. We continue investing in 4 priority areas. We are adding network capacity, achieving greater efficiency through technology, deploying industry-specific solutions and expanding in high-growth markets.
In Europe, we have completed about 1/4 of the projects associated with our $2 billion capital investment plan. During the second quarter, we announced new automated facilities in Belgium and France. In addition, we began an extensive program that would dramatically improve time and transit in our intra-Europe ground network, with some trade lanes improving by as much as 2 business days. The majority of the benefits of these investments are still ahead of us and would guarantee our position as a market leader in Europe for many years to come.
We're also investing heavily in our U.S. operations, and in a few minutes, Richard will update you on our technology and capacity projects. A pillar of our strategy in the U.S. is deploying industry-leading e-commerce capabilities that help online retailers take advantage of consumer trends.
We recently released the fifth annual U.S. Pulse of the Online Shopper study that highlights some of these changing trends. This year's survey revealed that most shoppers prefer home delivery, while also expressing an interest in an alternative delivery location. To provide more delivery options, UPS is expanding our Access Point locker program in several major U.S. markets. These automated pickup locations augment our more than 8,000 existing U.S. retail locations, and the more than 25,000 access points worldwide.
We're providing more convenient alternatives for urban online shoppers. New technology features were also introduced for the 24 million My Choice users in the U.S. For example, members can now use to follow My Delivery feature to track their package using real-time maps. These new capabilities are unique solutions to create value for our customers and further differentiate their online offering. Our investments are broad based and targeted for the needs of customers in multiple industries.
This quarter, we announced a specialized set of global services for health care companies performing clinical trials. And in Europe, we expanded our field stocking locations for medical device distributors. UPS health care customers are gaining additional alternatives for shipping their sensitive materials globally with the assurance of our guaranteed services.
UPS also launched a market-leading partnership with SAP and Fast Radius to support end-to-end 3D printing solutions. This capability is linked to more than 60 UPS store locations and the urgent delivery capabilities of the UPS network.
This partnership is enabling UPS to expand into an adjacent market with great growth potential. We entered another adjacent industry in 2015, with the acquisition of asset-light truckload brokerage services of Coyote Logistics. The combination of Coyote's capabilities and the UPS integrated network is providing customers with unmatched flexibility. Next month will mark the one year anniversary of the acquisition.
The synergies in procurement, asset utilization and cost selling remain on track to achieve our 2017 targets. In fact, cross-selling has already produced several great wins.
Before I turn it over to Richard, I want to take a moment to recognize a milestone we will achieve in August. UPS marks our 48th year in Germany and our entrance into Europe. Over that time, our business has matured rapidly and the European operations have become a cornerstone for our integrated network.
To date, we operate in every European country, generating more than $6 billion in annual revenue using our best-in-class pan-European network. The expansion in Europe and the growth of our business around the world are made possible through the hard work and dedication of UPSers.
As our strong momentum carries into the second half of the year, I want to thank all of our employees around the globe for helping make and maintain UPS as the market leader.
Now Richard will review the financial highlights.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, David. The second quarter operating results demonstrate the value of our flexible business model as we had another solid quarter. Additionally, we are seeing high growth in the e-commerce and health care sectors, while the LTL and forwarding marke
componenttext:
Thanks, David. The second quarter operating results demonstrate the value of our flexible business model as we had another solid quarter. Additionally, we are seeing high growth in the e-commerce and health care sectors, while the LTL and forwarding markets remain challenged.
Even with these dynamics, currency neutral revenue growth increased 4%, while fuel surcharges were dragged at around 120 basis points. Second quarter earnings per share were in line with expectations. Our performance reflected the gains from our investment strategies despite the mixed macro environment. The international segment outperformed, while U.S. domestic was on target. And finally, supply chain and freight was slightly below expectations.
Now for some details by segment. U.S. domestic revenue increased 2.4%, as lower fuel surcharges reduced total revenue growth by about 100 basis points. Average daily volume increased 2.5%, led by Next Day Air products, which were up about 6%. The Next Day Air gains were produced by customers of all sizes. Demand was consumer based as more online retailers are providing faster delivery options to stay competitive.
During the quarter, ground products increased 2.4% over last year, as B2C expansion outpaced B2B by more than 5:1. Base rates accelerated slightly from last quarter. Lower fuel surcharges reduced yield growth by about 100 basis points. The higher base rates were able to compensate for some of the changes in product and customer mix. Operating profit increased about 3% and operating margin expanded to 13.7%. Enhanced productivity and lower fuel costs resulted in operating cost per piece declining 0.02%.
Once again, we have seen good improvements in our daily operating statistics. Despite the fact that delivery stops were up over 3%, ORION lowered driver miles by 0.03%. In addition, overall productivity gains continued as direct labor hours grew less than the volume. Our investment in ORION is bending the cost curve, and we remain on track to complete Phase I implementation later in 2016.
We are continuing our multiyear investment strategy in hub automation in the U.S. operations. So far in 2016, we have announced new projects in California, Colorado, Illinois and Texas. These facilities are adding increased capacity and improved productivity.
Now turning to the International segment, which had another remarkable quarter, with operating profit expanding more than 11%. On a 2-year stack basis, operating profit is up more than 30%. Export daily volume increased almost 4% as improvements in all international regions offset slower U.S. exports. Europe led the way with significant gains in cross-border products and export growth to all regions of the world. In fact, the Europe to U.S. lane grew with double-digit pace this quarter.
Cycling out of the revenue management initiatives that we started in the last half of 2015, we have seen good non-U.S. domestic daily shipment growth, which is up 4.5%, while at the same time, currency neutral revenue per piece increased 1%.
We saw higher base rates. However, they were offset by changes in product and trade lane mix. Currency neutral revenue for the segment increased 1.5%. The lower fuel surcharge did impact revenue growth by about 170 basis points. The cost and productivity improvements held operating expenses down during the quarter. As a result of operating margin expanded to 19.9%. The international segment had a record second quarter, with its highest second quarter delivery volume, operating profit and one of the best margins ever.
Now let's turn and look at supply chain and freight. Total revenue increased more than 13% due to the addition of Coyote Logistics. The new truckload brokerage revenue offset tonnage shortfalls in international forwarding and the U.S. LTL business. Freight forwarding revenue and operating profit declined as we wrapped last year's rate actions. Cargo capacity continues to outpace demand, contributing to the weak market conditions I mentioned earlier. Expansion of the buy-sell rate and cost containment efforts led to the operating margin expansion. The unit remains focused on growing the more profitable middle market.
In the distribution unit, we experienced strong revenue growth in the health care, aerospace and automotive sectors this quarter. In fact, this quarter, health care became the top revenue sector within the contract logistics business.
Distribution operating profit jumped more than 10% and the margin expanded. The UPS Freight business remains disciplined on pricing, with revenue per hundredweight up 3%. The unit's execution of revenue quality initiatives is driving higher shipment yields. Total tonnage was lower by about 10%, due in part to the weak LTL market conditions.
Now to update you on our cash position. For the 6 months ended June 30, UPS generated $3.7 billion of free cash flow, a 13% increase over last year. And this was after spending $1 billion on CapEx. The company paid just over $1.3 billion in dividends, an increase of almost 7%. In addition, we purchased over 13 million shares for more than $1.3 billion. Combined, we are on schedule to meet our return to shareholders goals we set for the year.
Looking at the rest of the year, our strong international performance and the return on investments we are making in our network give us confidence in our ability to achieve our full-year earnings guidance of $5.70 to $5.90 per share. As I discussed in February, we expect 2016 operating profit by quarter to follow the same pattern as it did in 2015. We still expect the fourth quarter operating profit growth to be above our annual guidance, somewhere between 9% and 11%.
The additional workday between Thanksgiving and Christmas, the continued strength in e-commerce and our strategic investments position us well for another solid fourth quarter.
Looking at the segments. In the U.S. domestic, we expect strong fourth quarter results. However, we will face tough comparisons in the third as a result of 1 less operating day and lower workers' compensation costs last year. Therefore, we anticipate third quarter operating profit to be relatively flat year-over-year.
For the International segment, we expect to continue into the second half of the year the progress we've made with operating profit growth in the 8% to 12% range. The supply chain and freight segment is where we anticipate the current market trends in international air freight and the U.S. trucking markets to remain solid. In addition, lower fuel surcharges will weigh on reported revenue growth. Therefore, total annual revenue growth for the segment should be around 10%.
Now let's look at taxes. The faster growth of our profits from the International segment means that we'll have a slightly lower tax rate in 2016.
In summary, UPS's financial performance this year clearly demonstrates the value of our diverse business. We are embracing the opportunities created by the evolution of the global e-commerce marketplace as it expands beyond traditional retail base. We continue investing in strategic technologies, systems and expanded capacity. And by our execution, we are strengthening our leadership position.
At the halfway point of the year, our business is responding well to the changing macro environment, and we are confident about the remainder of 2016.
Thanks for your attention today. Now I'll ask the operator to open the line. Operator?

Maybe some of the advances you made, you talked about advancing 2 days on some of the service deliveries. What is accelerating that pace? And how are you achieving that operating margin gains?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ken, this is Jim. We talked over the years about the network in Europe. David referenced it in his opening comments. I think the key to our success in Europe has been and we'll continue to be making sure that network and the service and product offerings
componenttext: Ken, this is Jim. We talked over the years about the network in Europe. David referenced it in his opening comments. I think the key to our success in Europe has been and we'll continue to be making sure that network and the service and product offerings are best in class. And so that means always maintaining the network, putting the speed in and making sure that the customers feel the benefit of that. And as you've seen over the years, they have said that. Obviously, the marketplace is changing. In Europe, we know that as well. So what forces us to continue to relook and reevaluate everything we do, the margins, they've always been strong. I think I'll flip it to Richard to talk about the margins as well.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ken and Jim. I do want to point out that the margin of 19.9% is very strong, and it does include that multiyear hedge that we talked about on the call the last few quarters. So I want to remind you that even adjusting for that, we're still over a
componenttext: Thanks, Ken and Jim. I do want to point out that the margin of 19.9% is very strong, and it does include that multiyear hedge that we talked about on the call the last few quarters. So I want to remind you that even adjusting for that, we're still over a 17.5% margin, which is the highest in any player in the industry. And along that route, if you would call the currency, we've been using multiyear hedge strategy. And what happened is in 2015, you saw a lot of volatility in the year ago to the dollar from $1.35 down to $1.11. So 2017 will be a transition year where we expect to have somewhere around $300 million impact for the change in the currency. We have moved to a different hedge strategy because the volatility has increased so much on currency where we're using more rolling average so that year-over-year, going forward, we'll not see these dips if you see a lot of volatility in currency. But overall, that 17.5% is really a result of all the efforts that Jim just spoke, really putting together and making adjustments in the network and at the same time, the quality of revenues that we're bringing in.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from the line of Chris Wetherbee of Citi.
componenttext: Our next question will come from the line of Chris Wetherbee of Citi.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wanted to ask you about some of the comments around the third quarter domestic side relative to the fourth quarter. So I'm just guessing just probably some level of investment that you'd be happy to advance and exceed [ph] and you guys really start to sho
componenttext: Wanted to ask you about some of the comments around the third quarter domestic side relative to the fourth quarter. So I'm just guessing just probably some level of investment that you'd be happy to advance and exceed [ph] and you guys really start to shore up to get ready for that surge again. Just thinking about it on a year-over-year basis, I guess, I just want to try to make sure I understand the comment around the tougher comps from the third quarter domestic side. Are there specific cost items that we might expect this year that we didn't have last year? Just kind of want to make sure I understand sort of that cadence of domestic entering 3 [ph] and 4Q.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. This is Richard, Chris. And I think the first thing to keep in mind here is that we continue to see margin expansion. Because of operating days, how holidays well, things like that, it's not a linear movement of their expansion of the margin. But ov
componenttext: Okay. This is Richard, Chris. And I think the first thing to keep in mind here is that we continue to see margin expansion. Because of operating days, how holidays well, things like that, it's not a linear movement of their expansion of the margin. But over the year to year, we kind of guided that we continue to see improvement, expect to see going improvement as well. When you look at the third quarter specifically, there is 1 less workday, and that does have an impact. As well as last year, we had some workers' comp credits that won't repeat this coming year. So when you take all of that into account, you have to kind of look at -- and we did at the beginning of the year, understanding how the quarters would look. And what we saw is that we need to make sure that you guys had some transparency to understand that workday shifts some of the profit around. And if you look at this quarter, this quarter, we had a good improvement. And that improvement was really driven by the operational improvements, even though we saw so much volatility in fuel this year in the second quarter. We actually saw a 25% increase in fuel from April to June, so we were chasing the revenue. But when you step back and look at what we expect for the fourth quarter, we're going to have a strong fourth quarter. We're putting our plans in place and we look forward to completing 2016, very much like we told you we would at the beginning of the year.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from the line of David Vernon, Bernstein.
