componenttext: Great. Just want to follow up, Richard. Thanks for the overview on the international side there and the strength you're talking about continuing. And maybe some of the advances you made. You talked about advancing 2 days on some of the service deliveries. What is accelerating that pace? And how are you achieving that operating margin gains?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ken, this is Jim. We've talked over the years about the network in Europe. David referenced it in his opening comments. I think the key to our success in Europe has been and will continue to be making sure that network and the service and product offering
componenttext: Ken, this is Jim. We've talked over the years about the network in Europe. David referenced it in his opening comments. I think the key to our success in Europe has been and will continue to be making sure that network and the service and product offerings are best in class. And so that means always maintaining the network, putting the speed in and making sure that the customers feel the benefit of that. And as you've seen over the years, they have said that. Obviously, the marketplace is changing in Europe. We know that as well. So what forces us to continue to relook and reevaluate everything we do. The margins, they've always been strong. I think I'll flip it to Richard to talk about the margins as well.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ken and Jim. I do want to point out that the margin of 19.9% is very strong, and it does include that multiyear hedge that we talked about on the call the last few quarters. So I want to remind you that even adjusting for that, we're still over a
componenttext: Thanks, Ken and Jim. I do want to point out that the margin of 19.9% is very strong, and it does include that multiyear hedge that we talked about on the call the last few quarters. So I want to remind you that even adjusting for that, we're still over a 17.5% margin, which is the highest in any player in the industry. And along that route, if you recall, the currency, we've been using multiyear hedge strategy. And what happened is in 2015, you saw a lot of volatility in the year ago to the dollar from $1.35 down to $1.11. So 2017 will be a transition year where we expect to have somewhere around $300 million impact for the change in the currency. We have moved to a different hedge strategy because the volatility has increased so much on currency where we're using more rolling average so that year-over-year, going forward, we'll not see these dips if you see a lot of volatility in currency. But overall, that 17.5% is really a result of all the efforts that Jim just spoke, really putting together and making adjustments in the network and at the same time, the quality of revenues that we're bringing in.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from the line of Chris Wetherbee of Citi.
componenttext: Our next question will come from the line of Chris Wetherbee of Citi.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wanted to ask you about some of the comments around the third quarter domestic side relative to the fourth quarter. So I'm just guessing there's probably some level of investment that you'd be happy to advance at peak season when you guys really start to
componenttext: Wanted to ask you about some of the comments around the third quarter domestic side relative to the fourth quarter. So I'm just guessing there's probably some level of investment that you'd be happy to advance at peak season when you guys really start to shore up to get ready for that surge again. Just thinking about it on a year-over-year basis, I guess, I just want to try to make sure I understand the comment around the tougher comps from the third quarter domestic side. Are there specific cost items that we might expect this year that we didn't have last year? Just kind of want to make sure I understand sort of that cadence of domestic entering 3Q and 4Q.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. This is Richard, Chris. And I think the first thing to keep in mind here is that we continue to see margin expansion. Because of operating days, how holidays fall, things like that, it's not a linear movement of their expansion of the margin. But ov
componenttext: Okay. This is Richard, Chris. And I think the first thing to keep in mind here is that we continue to see margin expansion. Because of operating days, how holidays fall, things like that, it's not a linear movement of their expansion of the margin. But over the year to year, we kind of guided that we continue to see improvement, expect to see going improvement as well. When you look at the third quarter specifically, there is 1 less workday, and that does have an impact. As well as last year, we had some workers' comp credits that won't repeat this coming year. So when you take all of that into account, you have to kind of look at -- and we did at the beginning of the year, understanding how the quarters would look. And what we saw is that we need to make sure that you guys had some transparency to understand that workday shifts some of the profit around. And if you look at this quarter, this quarter, we had a good improvement. And that improvement was really driven by the operational improvements, even though we saw so much volatility in fuel this year in the second quarter. We actually saw a 25% increase in fuel from April to June, so we were chasing the revenue. But when you step back and look at what we expect for the fourth quarter, we're going to have a strong fourth quarter. We're putting our plans in place and we look forward to completing 2016, very much like we told you we would at the beginning of the year.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from the line of David Vernon, Bernstein.
componenttext: Our next question will come from the line of David Vernon, Bernstein.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe just following up on domestic, Richard. I guess, the step below sort of long-term guidance growth in that domestic segment, obviously, going down this quarter to 3% and then an expectation for flat in 3Q. Maybe to think over the course of the next s
componenttext: Maybe just following up on domestic, Richard. I guess, the step below sort of long-term guidance growth in that domestic segment, obviously, going down this quarter to 3% and then an expectation for flat in 3Q. Maybe to think over the course of the next sort of 1, 2, 3 years and that rate of margin change, how should we be expecting sort of that to happen to get to that longer-term 15%? And what do you think is going to be different about sort of next year and the year after that would [ph] let you get back to that kind of 8% growth that you guys have put out for a long-term target in domestic?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. First, if we step back, if you recall, when we guided this year and what we've seen through the year is we have seen some softness in macro measures. Everything has kind of come down each quarter of this year. And so we take that into account, obvi
componenttext: Great. First, if we step back, if you recall, when we guided this year and what we've seen through the year is we have seen some softness in macro measures. Everything has kind of come down each quarter of this year. And so we take that into account, obviously, with how we think about this year. The good part about this year is even with that softness, we're putting initiatives and investments in that are bringing returns, and that's why we're able to leave our guidance right where we expect it to be at the first part of the year. That being said, we are in a multiyear process of investments both in the ORION that David talked about in his talk as well as the hub automation and how that will continue. So all of those things are about putting together the multiyear process of where we're going to improve the margin that we laid out really at the end of '14. We're putting those investments in. Those investments are paying the return we expected. And we just expect, as we get more of that integrated into our network, we'll continue to see the benefits of that. So we feel very comfortable where we're at. We know where on a road map for the next few years and we're following that road map.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. This is David, and we're going to take an online question. This one is from Nate Brochmann.And as a large e-commerce shipper takes over more of its own delivery within the denser cities, does that change the density equation at all and the need to
componenttext:
Okay. This is David, and we're going to take an online question. This one is from Nate Brochmann.
And as a large e-commerce shipper takes over more of its own delivery within the denser cities, does that change the density equation at all and the need to retrofit all of the regional sort facilities? And how is that project progressing? And what have you learned thus far in terms of benefits heading into another peak?
So Nate got his bang for his buck in that question. And I will start and address the first part of it, then I'm going to turn it over to Myron to talk to a little bit about the retrofit and peak. And it's not unusual for any of our large shippers to make decisions, whether they're going to outsource or insource different parts of their business. Our focus is our diverse customer base, just makes it so difficult for any one company to be able to match our density, no matter their size. So with our integrated network, it creates efficiencies. We're constantly increasing our value proposition. So we always believe that our -- even our large customers would have more density with us than going in another direction. So I feel very confident in our strategy from that regard. Why don't you talk about the retrofit and peak preparation, Myron?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Nate, the process itself is going well, and we continue to realize 20% to 25% productivity improvements as we go along. Keep in mind, this is a multiyear, multiphase implementation. And you've heard about some of the cities that we introduced earlier i
componenttext: So Nate, the process itself is going well, and we continue to realize 20% to 25% productivity improvements as we go along. Keep in mind, this is a multiyear, multiphase implementation. And you've heard about some of the cities that we introduced earlier in Richard's comments. Our goal is to automate the top Tier 1 hubs, and there's approximately 30 of them in the U.S that process as much as 60% of our volume. Three of those automated hubs are in our air operation and the remainder will be in the ground. All new hubs moving forward will be built using an automated design, and the second phase of it will be to go to the Tier 2 hubs and automate them as well. So we feel very good about the progress that's being made, and we're on plan and the goal is to get it completed no later than 2020.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from the line of Mr. Tom Wadewitz of UBS.
componenttext: Our next question will come from the line of Mr. Tom Wadewitz of UBS.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask a bit specific about ORION. I know, Richard, you offered some comments on kind of the high-level multiyear productivity and so forth. But is there -- is 2017 -- or are you starting to see this year where there's the reduction in the rollou
componenttext: I wanted to ask a bit specific about ORION. I know, Richard, you offered some comments on kind of the high-level multiyear productivity and so forth. But is there -- is 2017 -- or are you starting to see this year where there's the reduction in the rollout costs and really getting some of the cost savings coming in, in a bigger way? Is -- are you starting to see that? Or is that something which would be maybe a bigger support for domestic margin performance in 2017? And then, you've mentioned a Phase 2. I don't know if you want to comment on that. I know that's a couple of questions, maybe just some perspective, a little more detail on ORION.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Tom. What I'll do is I'll start off, and then I'll hand it off to Myron to talk specifically about the benefits he's seen. But when you think about the investment and when we've been on the road talking about ORION, we have talked about that later t
componenttext: Sure, Tom. What I'll do is I'll start off, and then I'll hand it off to Myron to talk specifically about the benefits he's seen. But when you think about the investment and when we've been on the road talking about ORION, we have talked about that later this year, we'll complete, call it, the first phase of ORION. And then we are investing the dollars in, call it, Phases 2 and 3 and 4. But on top of that, it's not just the investment in ORION. It's also the investment in hub automation and what that does to the network. So we are using those investment dollars and the, call it, the additional expense that we were using to train up for ORION in other ways so that we get the end results. And that's kind of what we talked about at the end of '14, and we continue to talk about each year. We are investing in our network, and it's pulling through when you see the reduction in miles and things like that. But the next phase is additional capabilities that will save money and then additional features by having the hub mod and there's some other things that we're working on as well just a little too early to go into. With that, I'm going to send it to Myron to talk just a little bit about what he's seen operationally with the results of ORION.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tom, let me start with we expect to be 100% fully deployed by the end of 2016 with ORION. And we will continue to see the benefits that we have alluded to earlier, more than 8 miles per driver in savings. For example, this quarter, we saw our delivery sto
componenttext: Tom, let me start with we expect to be 100% fully deployed by the end of 2016 with ORION. And we will continue to see the benefits that we have alluded to earlier, more than 8 miles per driver in savings. For example, this quarter, we saw our delivery stops grow more than 3% on 2.5% average daily volume gains. However, we were able to reduce our miles driven by 0.3%, which helped keep our costs per piece down by 0.2%. So as the volume continues to grow, our wages are growing at a lesser pace than the volume. So we're continuing to see benefits. And there -- that's Phase 1. Phase 2 will actually begin in the back half of this year, well into 2017, and we hope to have this Phase 2 completed by 2017, but we hope to see additional benefits from ORION. And again, that's just one of many technology projects that we'll continue to roll out that should help us continue to bend the cost curves. So we're really pleased with what we are seeing.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from the line of Mr. Scott Group of Wolfe Research.
componenttext: Our next question will come from the line of Mr. Scott Group of Wolfe Research.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So actually, just want to follow up on the ORION question. So understand that there's savings this year, but there's probably some implementation costs. Can you quantify what the implementation costs are this year and if ORION has been a net positive or t
componenttext: So actually, just want to follow up on the ORION question. So understand that there's savings this year, but there's probably some implementation costs. Can you quantify what the implementation costs are this year and if ORION has been a net positive or tailwind to earnings this year? And do you think that next year -- how do you think about next year given the savings from Phase 1, but maybe the costs from Phase 2? Any color in there would be helpful.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So again, this is Richard. And yes, we are seeing the savings. And if you just step back for a moment and look, year-over-year, we continue to see the margin expansion. The margin expansion is a direct result of all the things Myron just talked abou
componenttext: Sure. So again, this is Richard. And yes, we are seeing the savings. And if you just step back for a moment and look, year-over-year, we continue to see the margin expansion. The margin expansion is a direct result of all the things Myron just talked about. We'll continue to see those improvements and it is a net positive, but we also are spending some of the savings in order to invest in the next phase and the next capability. And those are all important pieces, and that's why -- my comment a few minutes ago about the margin will improve year-over-year. It won't always be linear by quarter. And so that's an important part because we are investing for new capabilities and to continue to bend the cost curve because of the investments we are making and the plans we have for the next few years.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is David. Just want to stress that ORION is one of these things that -- it's the gift that keeps on giving. So what we have seen with ORION is we're seeing benefits that are greater than what we originally believed, and that continues to reinforce it
componenttext: This is David. Just want to stress that ORION is one of these things that -- it's the gift that keeps on giving. So what we have seen with ORION is we're seeing benefits that are greater than what we originally believed, and that continues to reinforce itself every year. We have a lot more we're going to accomplish through ORION with the later versions and taking it to various countries. So we're very positive about ORION and about the returns that we're getting. And the investments that we're making are certainly worth it.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question will come from the line of Brandon Oglenski of Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Next question will come from the line of Brandon Oglenski of Barclays Capital.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: As we look out, can you talk about where the pricing is falling in the U.S. domestic market? And why, with this tremendous growth in B2C, that we're not seeing a little bit much traction on yields, which, I think, could also talk to this part -- or is thi
componenttext: As we look out, can you talk about where the pricing is falling in the U.S. domestic market? And why, with this tremendous growth in B2C, that we're not seeing a little bit much traction on yields, which, I think, could also talk to this part -- or is this discussion on domestic margins. Because obviously, we've talked a lot about cost. But what are we doing on the revenue side? And is there ability to take more price?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Brandon, this is Alan. Thanks for the question. So for the quarter, we achieved our 2% to 3% range in our base pricing, and the core pricing actually remains firm. We actually saw a bit of an acceleration from the first quarter. Keep in mind that som
componenttext: Yes. Brandon, this is Alan. Thanks for the question. So for the quarter, we achieved our 2% to 3% range in our base pricing, and the core pricing actually remains firm. We actually saw a bit of an acceleration from the first quarter. Keep in mind that some of the other phenomena we're seeing out there is the offset of about 100 basis points due to lower fuel surcharges, and we're continuing [ph] to see changes in the customers and product mix and specifically, the cat -- package characteristics as we bring more lightweight into the business. The other thing I would say is that we saw -- even with some of those package characteristics and customer product mix, challenges, we did see margin improvement overall in the U.S. domestic business. So we think the base rate improvements remains steady, and they will continue to remain that way and core pricing right now is firm.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question will come from the line of Scott Schneeberger of Oppenheimer.
componenttext: Next question will come from the line of Scott Schneeberger of Oppenheimer.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just curious here, at the midpoint of the year, obviously, reiterating the guidance range. I'm curious, looking out over the second half, what do you view as the swing factors that would put you toward the high end to the low end of the range?
componenttext: Just curious here, at the midpoint of the year, obviously, reiterating the guidance range. I'm curious, looking out over the second half, what do you view as the swing factors that would put you toward the high end to the low end of the range?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Scott. This is Richard. And I think when you start and you look at where we're at year-to-date, first of all, in earnings per share, we're at about 8.5% growth in earnings per share on a full -- at a target of 5% to 9%. So we're pleased with where w
componenttext: Sure, Scott. This is Richard. And I think when you start and you look at where we're at year-to-date, first of all, in earnings per share, we're at about 8.5% growth in earnings per share on a full -- at a target of 5% to 9%. So we're pleased with where we are for the first half of the year. We're actually right in line with where we expected to be. But when we look at guidance, there's really 2 factors we're looking at. The first is the external and what's happening on the external measures because that -- our volume does have some correlation, especially when you get to B2B to what's happening with both domestic GDP, things like industrial production and things like that, and they all have softened somewhat from first quarter to second quarter. The other side of it, of course, is what's happening internally, the things Myron has talked about in his operation. And those improvements that we're seeing. So we put all that together, and we say do we have economic -- assumptions are realistic? And then how are we benefiting from the initiatives that we've implemented? And so we think we've balanced all that, and that's what we're seeing in 2016. We're seeing a nice balance where we're making up for some softness externally with what we're doing internally, and that's allowed us to grow our earnings per share for 6 quarters in a row, and we'll continue to work those plans for guidance going forward.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just to add to Richard's answer, it's our investments and strategies that have allowed us to offset some of these economic shifts that we've seen in the last 1.5 years. And we feel very comfortable about our strategic initiatives. We are extremely focu
componenttext:
So just to add to Richard's answer, it's our investments and strategies that have allowed us to offset some of these economic shifts that we've seen in the last 1.5 years. And we feel very comfortable about our strategic initiatives. We are extremely focused on them and it's allowing us to overcome some of those headwinds.
We'll take the next question. We'll do an online question. This is from Helane Becker. And it's, are you seeing any signs of weakness in the U.K. related to anything, including Brexit? Jim?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So David, thanks for that one and Helane as well. I think I get this question every day, quite frankly, over the last couple of months. But I think to give a little bit of backdrop, when I go back to -- and just remind you of something here. Back in 2008,
componenttext: So David, thanks for that one and Helane as well. I think I get this question every day, quite frankly, over the last couple of months. But I think to give a little bit of backdrop, when I go back to -- and just remind you of something here. Back in 2008, when we bought Lynx, it was our choice in the U.K. to strengthen that market. To feed the network, we talked about a lot and obviously, also feed that country and the consumers. It took us a couple of years to get it done. We're done in 2010. And although we don't talk much about country-level performance, I think, this question will get us pretty close to it. I could just tell you that from the years 2010 through '15, that U.K. operation for us is best in class in many ways that we measure our business. So that acquisition and integration, that took us about 3 years, has paid dividends for many, many, many years now. Brexit, we don't see changing that for that market quite frankly. Our job is to continue that priority, number one, to take care of that economy and the consumers, our employees and the shareholders and link it into that European network. So that's priority 1. The issue obviously becomes what this free trade agreement's set up to be. Don't forget a couple of things, I think, for my perspective. One is, there are many -- there is a number of free trade agreements in that union as well. You've got the Norway model, you got the Swiss model and then you've got the EU model. So how it unfolds, we will see, but there are various models that could unfold. We've analyzed scenarios as far left as the WTO setup, all the way back to something close to what they have today. In the end, I think our priority is to advise and advocate and support consumers as the free trade agreements are finalized in the coming years, and then continue to whatever happens, support that market and the network, and I think we could easily say there will be somewhat more complexity. But I think our job is to simplify the complex in the network for consumers and continue the great service, and that's what we plan to do as that unfolds.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from the line of Ben Hartford of Baird.
componenttext: Our next question will come from the line of Ben Hartford of Baird.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wondering what your point of view is today on the acquisition environment as you start to lap the Coyote acquisition? Obviously, taking into account what you said historically about acquisition criteria, are there specific segments or verticals that
componenttext: Just wondering what your point of view is today on the acquisition environment as you start to lap the Coyote acquisition? Obviously, taking into account what you said historically about acquisition criteria, are there specific segments or verticals that you're more interested in? And then I guess, I'm leading you into UPS Freight in particular. Given some of the softness that we've seen, in that LTL market, do you think that, that business is at sufficient scale today or are there potential acquisition opportunities in that segment, specifically?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, Ben. Thanks for the question. This is David. And I'll answer the first part. And then you talked a little bit about Coyote, so I'll ask Alan to briefly hit that and then the LTL environment, and Myron will take that. But from an acquisition standpoi
componenttext: Okay, Ben. Thanks for the question. This is David. And I'll answer the first part. And then you talked a little bit about Coyote, so I'll ask Alan to briefly hit that and then the LTL environment, and Myron will take that. But from an acquisition standpoint, we have an active process. And we're really looking in what I'll call just 3 general buckets that we're always taking a look at. First is new opportunities, new opportunities that would help us add more value to our customers and then, any time that we can expand capability within our networks. So if it's something that we don't feel as strong about as we'd like to, then that would be that second criteria. And then, third, the trade lanes are shifting throughout the world, and so geographic presence is always important. Over the last few years, the emerging markets has been a place that we put a lot of attention on. So adjacent markets, which is what we did with the Coyote acquisition, is keen on our mind. But at the end of the day, whether it's organic growth or it's inorganic growth, our focus is on growing this business and at the same time, having profitable returns. So from a Coyote standpoint, Alan?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, just a quick update on Coyote. Certainly, their customers and our customers and new customers are responding very well to the new Coyote and UPS combined value prop. For the quarter, we continue to see strong year-over-year growth in loads. And our g
componenttext: Yes, just a quick update on Coyote. Certainly, their customers and our customers and new customers are responding very well to the new Coyote and UPS combined value prop. For the quarter, we continue to see strong year-over-year growth in loads. And our gross margin is also expanded for the quarter. As I think we all know, the truckload market remained soft. But certainly, this asset-light model has provided some great flexibility in the up and down cycles. And then just lastly, I'll just say that as far as the synergies related to the acquisition, we're seeing some good work happening there in procurement, asset utilization, cross-selling and then organizational synergies that are benefiting both Coyote and also our U.S. domestic and Supply Chain Freight segments and we're on track. And now I guess, I'll turn it over to Myron to talk a little bit about the LTL.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ben, as you are well aware, the LTL market for the last 16 consecutive months has experienced softness. And our customer base is telling us that they have high inventory levels. And in addition to that, with high inventory levels, the opportunity for rest
componenttext: Ben, as you are well aware, the LTL market for the last 16 consecutive months has experienced softness. And our customer base is telling us that they have high inventory levels. And in addition to that, with high inventory levels, the opportunity for restocking is soft as well. All those things considered, we believe that we have the appropriate scale at UPS Freight. We will have or continue to monitor the market and make the appropriate adjustments and make the right business decisions moving forward in terms of whether or not to expand our scale.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question will come from the line of Allison Landry of Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: The next question will come from the line of Allison Landry of Crédit Suisse.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could you speak a little more to your earlier comments about U.S. consumer interest and alternative delivery methods? I wanted to understand how well penetrated it is, even in the urban areas and specifically, how much you think it would to increase from
componenttext: Could you speak a little more to your earlier comments about U.S. consumer interest and alternative delivery methods? I wanted to understand how well penetrated it is, even in the urban areas and specifically, how much you think it would to increase from here in order to move the needle on density?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks for the question, Allison. This is Alan. There's a number of things, first of all, that we're doing to improve density, and it's really part of the whole e-commerce value proposition and ecosystem that we've put in place. The UPS Access Points
componenttext: Yes. Thanks for the question, Allison. This is Alan. There's a number of things, first of all, that we're doing to improve density, and it's really part of the whole e-commerce value proposition and ecosystem that we've put in place. The UPS Access Points, UPS My Choice, the Synchronized Delivery Solutions and certainly, SurePost Redirect, which is now at about the 30% of those packages are being redirected back into the Ground network. On Access Points, right now, we'll probably finish the year at about 27,000 access points, globally and we continue to expand there. So yes, so when you think about bending the cost curve, I guess, the 1/10 contributes to about $200 million in bottom line costs, if we -- when we increase the density by 1/10. And then I guess, the last thing I'll say is that we continue to be bullish about Access Points, and we're expanding the current model. And as you probably saw, we invested in our locker expansion after some tests we ran last year, and we're laying in 300 lockers into the United States in the -- your point about urban America and urban anywhere in the world, lots of consumers out there who have challenges receiving packages at home in urban areas and the Access Points and the lockers is a great solution for them and it also benefits UPS.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from the line of David Ross of Stifel.
componenttext: Our next question will come from the line of David Ross of Stifel.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: You've talked a lot about the U.S. and also about Europe. Can you talk a little bit more about Asia and the rest of the world, what you're seeing going on there from a trade perspective?
componenttext: You've talked a lot about the U.S. and also about Europe. Can you talk a little bit more about Asia and the rest of the world, what you're seeing going on there from a trade perspective?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: David , this is Jim. Certainly, the Asia market, it also continues to change. Our -- obviously, the biggest market out there from a China perspective. We currently, quite frankly, are seeing very, very nice and actually, momentum picking up in our middle
componenttext: David , this is Jim. Certainly, the Asia market, it also continues to change. Our -- obviously, the biggest market out there from a China perspective. We currently, quite frankly, are seeing very, very nice and actually, momentum picking up in our middle market growth based upon the solutions we're providing to the Chinese consumer as their model shifts at the same time. Certainly, the network that we have in place has served us well for many years. This quarter, overall, I think the block hours were down about 0.5%. You saw in the early opening comments of the call this morning and the releases that the export volume continues to grow at UPS, and that includes our Asia Pacific region as well as our Latin America region at the same time. So we continue on. One of our big focuses out there is our intra-Asia network. It's a great opportunity for us. We've laid that in, in 2010. We think it has lots more upside. We'll continue to do that and really align that as well to the emerging market strategy that David just referenced a minute ago that we continue to invest in and I'm confident we'll be referencing on the calls to come. So I appreciate the question.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from the line of Jack Atkins of Stephens.
componenttext: Our next question will come from the line of Jack Atkins of Stephens.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I was wondering if you could expand for a moment on your comments around B2B trends? You referenced in the press release that B2C grew 5x that of B2B, but could you maybe comment exactly sort of what the growth rate was for B2B in the quarter? Sort of
componenttext: So I was wondering if you could expand for a moment on your comments around B2B trends? You referenced in the press release that B2C grew 5x that of B2B, but could you maybe comment exactly sort of what the growth rate was for B2B in the quarter? Sort of what portion of your U.S. Domestic Package business, B2B, makes up now? And sort of what customer verticals are you seeing particular strength or weakness on the B2B side?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is Alan. I'll take that question. On the commercial B2B side, we did see a slight increase. We -- the good news is we've seen a slight increase the last few quarters there. It's mainly being driven actually by the retail sector and returns. But
componenttext: Yes. This is Alan. I'll take that question. On the commercial B2B side, we did see a slight increase. We -- the good news is we've seen a slight increase the last few quarters there. It's mainly being driven actually by the retail sector and returns. But we are seeing some growth in some other areas. Wholesale, health care and professional services are some of the areas and also consumer and home goods. As you know, industrial production, as I think, David indicated, was pretty soft, and the B2B is really being driven now by retail and some of those other sectors that I've spoken about. I think our investments really in some of these sectors, including health care, are helping us to gain share in that particular area, so kind of outrun the economic challenges. And then lastly, our B2C business is about 45% of our business today.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. The next question will come from online. And the question is -- and this was from the buy side is, do you see any long term opportunities to expand streamlined delivery routes with the ride sharing programs? So Alan?
componenttext: Okay. The next question will come from online. And the question is -- and this was from the buy side is, do you see any long term opportunities to expand streamlined delivery routes with the ride sharing programs? So Alan?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, David. Yes, I think, again, everyone knows on the call that we made a strategic enterprise fund investment a few quarters back in a company named Deliv, which is a retail-to-consumer same-day B2C delivery company that actually uses the excess capa
componenttext: Thanks, David. Yes, I think, again, everyone knows on the call that we made a strategic enterprise fund investment a few quarters back in a company named Deliv, which is a retail-to-consumer same-day B2C delivery company that actually uses the excess capacity out there on the market with people that have vehicles that want to participate in that program, similar to what's happening on the ride sharing part of the economy there. They're a leader in this new space, and we're excited to learn more from that. The other thing I would say is that Coyote is really a technology platform that's doing the same thing. It's matching up excess capacity in the marketplace from thousands upon thousands of carriers that have backhaul excess capacity. And we're providing a similar service with Coyote. So we are excited about that in the heavier truckload type business as well as for the prospects potentially on the pickup and delivery side.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from the line of Kelly Dougherty of Macquarie.
componenttext: Our next question will come from the line of Kelly Dougherty of Macquarie.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to think about the U.S. domestic volume growth. Obviously, things like Prime are driving demand from more premium products, but would love to get some insight on how other retailers are pursuing e-commerce if they're offering free shipping on
componenttext: Just wanted to think about the U.S. domestic volume growth. Obviously, things like Prime are driving demand from more premium products, but would love to get some insight on how other retailers are pursuing e-commerce if they're offering free shipping on some or all spending levels. Do you expect that will show up more in your deferred offerings? Though that certainly seems to be the case this quarter. Just trying to get a sense of what you think the volume and maybe the revenue mix will be at e-commerce growth?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So this is Alan. A couple of points on your question. First, the holiday offerings here in July were pretty widespread amongst a whole number of retailers, and I think we'll see more and more of that certainly in this summer time frame, but also in o
componenttext: Yes. So this is Alan. A couple of points on your question. First, the holiday offerings here in July were pretty widespread amongst a whole number of retailers, and I think we'll see more and more of that certainly in this summer time frame, but also in other parts of the year to drive growth in the e-commerce sector for these retailers, which is critically important for them. The -- certainly, the e-commerce growth drives significant growth in our ground business and our SurePost business and then on the overnight and deferred side, mainly in the Saver and the second day air (sic) [Next Day Air] business. But the key here is that we've got this great portfolio. So when a customer absolutely has to have it, they're usually willing to pay for that, and we have the full gamut of services to get those goods to them when they want it. And then we have the more economical alternatives along with some of the other value adds like UPS Access Point, UPS My Choice and omnichannel that really drive those retailers and those consumers to UPS.

componenttext: I guess, this is piggybacking on Kelly's question. Can you walk us through some of the factors that were impacting U.S. Domestic Package deferred volume and yield trends, which have diverged a little bit from the rest of the U.S. domestic portfolio with volumes than a little bit but yields up year-on-year? And if you could specifically address if we're seeing the impact of any large customers changing their delivery methodology that are impacting deferred trends.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Alan. I'll take that. First, our premium Next Day Air products grew at nearly 6%, and the ground was up more than 2%. So certainly, our customers are responding to the continual expansion of our Next Day Air and our Next Day Air Early service
componenttext: Yes, this is Alan. I'll take that. First, our premium Next Day Air products grew at nearly 6%, and the ground was up more than 2%. So certainly, our customers are responding to the continual expansion of our Next Day Air and our Next Day Air Early service to more postal codes. In fact, all of our Next Day Air services experienced growth. On the other hand, Saver, Ground and SurePost and certainly deferred are focused more on the e-commerce and retail customers. And so on the deferred side, you really need to look at it on a 2-year stack basis. We almost grew 15%, following strong double-digit growth in 2015.

componenttext: And I'm going to try and squeeze in 2 follow-ups, if I can. The first one is on 2017. So between the FX hedges rolling off and the Ground growth costs, do you think EBIT can be higher in 2017 versus '16? And the second question is on Amazon. Do you feel like your delivery share with them has held constant? Or is it up or down in the last 12 months?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Ravi, this is Richard, and I'll start with the first question on the guidance for '17. And I think the important thing is we have said that as we move forward, we have continued initiatives that will continue to improve the operating margin. That being
componenttext: So Ravi, this is Richard, and I'll start with the first question on the guidance for '17. And I think the important thing is we have said that as we move forward, we have continued initiatives that will continue to improve the operating margin. That being said, obviously, different segments, things will happen and growth rates might have to be adjusted. It's a little early to talk about exactly what's going to happen, and that's really because there's a lot of things going on, and volatility of currency too. So the year is -- here we are in end of July, we have time still. And if you tell me where, in November, the dollar-euro is or the sterling-dollar, that will be a lot about the story of how much variation. That's why we say the plus or minus numbers. The important thing is that we have a plan. It will improve by segment. Our first priority is to reinvest in this business because of the strength of the company. We continue to deliver the highest ROIC and the highest margins in the business, and our plan is to continue to do that. And we will continue to do that while at the same time, having dividends of over 3% or around 3%. So as we get closer to 2017, I'll guide you appropriately, but we are in the middle of putting all those plans together. And then your second question around the percentage of our share of any one customer, it's something that we -- we obviously continue to win customers based on our strategy. To win customers, we don't come in any one customer, but you can see our volume growth for the U.S. was up about 2.5%. You adjust for fuel, we saw revenue growth of about 3.4%. So it was a strong quarter. We laid out for you how we think the fourth quarter is going to look, and that's another strong quarter. And we're going to end up delivering on the guidance numbers that we gave you at the beginning of the year. And I think that's the most important thing.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. We have one last question, and this is an online question from Tyler Brown [ph]. And it's about return logistics, reverse logistics and kind of a 2 part. Could you talk about what kind of growth rates you're seeing in return volumes? And talk a litt
componenttext: Okay. We have one last question, and this is an online question from Tyler Brown [ph]. And it's about return logistics, reverse logistics and kind of a 2 part. Could you talk about what kind of growth rates you're seeing in return volumes? And talk a little bit about our capabilities on this front. And do we need to do something to add to our capabilities? So Alan if you'd take that?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks for the question, Tyler [ph]. Yes, as I said earlier, returns growth has been strong. It's in the midteens. And as you all know, returns is very good business for us because customers tend to drop those packages off, so we have high-density pi
componenttext: Yes. Thanks for the question, Tyler [ph]. Yes, as I said earlier, returns growth has been strong. It's in the midteens. And as you all know, returns is very good business for us because customers tend to drop those packages off, so we have high-density pickups at those dropoff locations and then high-density deliveries back to the retailers. Now UPS has some of the most technology advanced transportation return services, with things like Returns on the Web, RS1, RS3, Print Label Return. So when it comes to label generation, shipping, tracking, visibility, enabling speed and refunds for the consumers, for customer experience, we've got some of the best returns solutions in the business. Combine that with the UPS Stores, the UPS Access Points, the lockers, the other alliance partners, UPS Drop Boxes, there are millions of packages being returned or being delivered to those dropoff locations, casting that wide net. And again, I just tie that back to the whole e-commerce ecosystem that we have that really benefits retailers and consumers and makes UPS the e-commerce transportation company of choice.

componenttext: Okay. So UPS performed well in the second quarter. We expanded our margins in our international and in our domestic small package business. And very importantly, we are investing today to ensure our future performance. So we're at the halfway point of the year. So to UPSers, this is halftime, and we've had a good first half. We were on plan. But it's very important that we're all committed to our plans and confident in our 2016 guidance. So on behalf of the 435,000 UPSers around the world, thank you for your time today. And for all of you, thank you for investing in UPS. Thank you very much.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Steven, and I will be your conference facilitator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the UPS Investor Relations Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to
componenttext:
Good morning. My name is Steven, and I will be your conference facilitator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the UPS Investor Relations Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] 
It is now my pleasure to turn the floor over to your host, Mr. Scott Childress, Investor Relations Officer. Sir, the floor is yours. Please go ahead.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the UPS Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. Joining me today are David Abney, our CEO; Richard Peretz, our CFO; along with International President, Jim Barber; President of U.S. Operations, Myron Gray; and Chief Commercial Offic
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the UPS Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. Joining me today are David Abney, our CEO; Richard Peretz, our CFO; along with International President, Jim Barber; President of U.S. Operations, Myron Gray; and Chief Commercial Officer, Alan Gershenhorn. Also joining us today is Kate Gutmann, our Chief Sales and Solutions Officer.
Before we begin, I want to review the Safe Harbor language. Some of the statements we'll make today are forward-looking statements that address our expectations for the future performance or results of operations of our company. These statements are subject to risks and uncertainties, which are described in detail in our 2015 Form 10-K.
This report is available on the UPS Investor Relations website and from the Securities and Exchange Commission. The webcast of today's call, along with the reconciliation of non-GAAP financial measures, are available on the UPS Investor Relations website.
Webcast users can submit live questions during today's call. We will attempt to answer questions of a long-term strategic nature. Callers are asked to submit only one question so that we may allow as many possible to participate. 
Thanks for your cooperation. Now I will turn the call over to David.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks Scott, and good morning, everyone. I'm pleased with our performance and happy to report another quarter of solid UPS earnings. These results demonstrate increased demand for our products and disciplined execution of our initiatives. I'll provide
componenttext:
Thanks Scott, and good morning, everyone. I'm pleased with our performance and happy to report another quarter of solid UPS earnings. These results demonstrate increased demand for our products and disciplined execution of our initiatives. 
I'll provide an update of our Q3 highlights, and then Kate will give you an update on peak season. 
During Q3, the International segment increased operating profit by 14% on more than 7% package volume growth. 
Our international strategy is achieving outstanding results. This was the seventh consecutive quarter of double-digit operating profit expansion. Yes, I said, seventh consecutive quarters of international operating profit growth. 
The U.S. domestic business produced higher than anticipated package volume, driven by strong demand for our portfolio of e-commerce solutions. We continue to see increased demand for our air products, and this quarter was no exception. 
Shippers are choosing UPS air products because our value is a differentiator. 
The Supply Chain & Freight segment is navigating prolonged weak market conditions. We are making progress in adapting their business model and focusing on capturing the right revenue opportunities.
We are confident in our long-term strategies, and as a result of our performance this quarter, we remain on plan with this year's guidance.
Turning now to the economy, where global growth has continued to be modest. 
In the U.S., consumer fundamentals remain healthy and account for most of the economic expansion, while the outlook for industrial production remains weak. Overall, global GDP forecasts are slightly down. For the balance of 2016, we continue to see mixed economic signals across some industrial markets. 
Under these conditions, our diversified business model and our winning strategies still enable UPS to take advantage of the high-growth markets, such as cross-border trade and e-commerce.
To facilitate growth, we are adding capacity and increasing efficiency in our globally-integrated network. Trade lane and product portfolio enhancements are important components of our plans. 
We have significantly improved time-in-transit from several cities in the U.S. and Canada based on increased export opportunities. We have also dramatically improved service times for cross-border shipments between several major European cities. 
During the quarter, we strengthened our portfolio of urgent delivery options by expanding our worldwide Express Plus product. We've doubled the number of countries served and are now reaching 90% of the world's GDP by the next day. 
We've also expanded solutions for our specialized shippers by strengthening our clinical trial service used by pharmaceutical companies. We see excellent opportunities for growth in this part of the health care segment. 
Our actions are providing more delivery options, faster transit times and earlier guaranteed deliveries, helping UPS customers achieve their growth objectives.
In addition, we are following a disciplined capital approach to invest in our business. 
In 2016, we announced 12 highly-automated facility upgrades as part of our multiyear strategy, and we plan to announce several significant new projects before the end of the year. These projects will help us to increase operating efficiencies, while simultaneously better serving our customers.
Expectations in the e-commerce sector and specialized markets, like health care logistics, have continued to shift to faster delivery options. As a result, demand for both domestic and international air products has been strong. 
Since we took delivery of our last new plane in 2013, UPS Air Products have increased more than 15%. Clearly, over the last several years, UPS has expanded market share in the air segment, and we expect these trends to continue. 
In response, we are announcing the purchase of 14 Boeing 747-8 jumbo freighters, along with options to buy 14 more in the future. We will take delivery of the first 2 at the end of 2017. This is a net add to our fleet. These new 747s will enable UPS to begin a cascade of aircraft route assignments that will add significant capacity in our busiest lanes.
This would optimize global air network capacity, these new cargo jets. All of these investments are in line to meet expanding customer needs and produce positive financial returns.
Looking now at the upcoming holiday season, we have created extensive [indiscernible] and plans and built the foundation for another successful holiday for our customers and shareholders. Our strategy is to follow the same framework outlined last year. It's the 4 Cs: collaboration, capacity, control and commitment.
To conclude, I want to recognize the hard-working and dedicated UPS-ers around the world for the progress we've made year-to-date and to thank them in advance for their commitment to another successful peak season.
And now Kate will update you on our peak plans.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, David, and good morning, everyone. It's my pleasure to review our 2016 Peak Season plans with you. The dramatic growth of online shopping and subsequent returns is expected to lift UPS package levels to a record high during this upcoming holiday
componenttext:
Thanks, David, and good morning, everyone. It's my pleasure to review our 2016 Peak Season plans with you. 
The dramatic growth of online shopping and subsequent returns is expected to lift UPS package levels to a record high during this upcoming holiday period. Between Thanksgiving and New Year's Eve 2016, there are 2 additional operating days, and we expect to complete over 700 million deliveries worldwide, about 100 million more than last year. 
In the overall U.S. market, the National Retail Federation expects total holiday retail sales to increase 3.6%. They are also estimating non-store retail sales growth between 7% and 10%. 
At UPS, our peak strategies are focused on executing the 4 Cs that David mentioned earlier. 
To begin with, we've deepened the level of collaboration with even more customers. We started earlier and our communicating more frequently. This better aligns UPS solutions and capacity with their seasonal promotion plans and fulfillment strategy, helping customers ship demand, sell inventory earlier and optimize their operation.
Customer experience continues to gain importance in the marketplace, making collaboration as shared objective for both shippers and UPS. Whether you're in health care, retail or any industry, our work together is creating consumer loyalty and a preference for the UPS delivery experience.
Looking at our second area of focus, capacity, UPS customers will benefit from several key automation and expansion projects. We've opened new automated facilities and updated existing hubs in the U.S. and Europe in cities such as Chicago, Los Angeles, Paris and London. In the U.S., we are supplementing our capacity with the addition of temporary facilities. These investments and technology and capacity make our integrated network more flexible and efficient.
This peak, our partners at Coyote Logistics will be supporting our entire domestic operation, helping UPS help customer needs during this high demand period. 
In addition, our driver dispatch will be even more effective. I'm pleased to announce that we've completed Phase 1 of the ORION implementation in the U.S., ahead of schedule. 100% of eligible U.S. drivers will be utilizing this dispatch technology during peak, up from 70% last year. 
The third focus area is control, both control of deliveries for UPS customers and control of the UPS network.
UPS My Choice will provide greater control to 30 million global members, an increase of 10 million from last year. My Choice enables members to exert preferences with their inbound UPS shipment and take action on their packages when desired. They can choose to redirect delivers to alternate delivery locations, including a UPS Access Point location.
In fact, this year, we've expanded our reach and we'll have over 27,000 convenient Access Point locations opened around the world, with approximately 8,000 in the U.S. 
Looking at the UPS network, we are exercising real-time control to ensure our customers can properly respond to peak demand, and one important tool we use is the UPS Control Tower. This decision-making body enables us to say yes to more customer request, leveraging the flexibility of our operations to accept volume surges when possible.
It also assures that our capacity, value, cost to serve and price are appropriately aligned throughout peak season. 
The final area of focus for UPS is commitment. The 450,000 UPS employees, together with 95,000 temporary hires, will be working diligently to provide world-class value in service during this upcoming holiday season. 
Each year, the needs of peak season create special memories for all UPS-ers. Last year, I had a chance to visit the building I started in, 27 years ago, the same energy, determination and customer focus that I was drawn to Day 1, was clear in everyone I met.  Spending time making deliveries really reinforced to me how the peak planning and collaboration with customers resonate throughout the entire organization. 
Thank you for your time today. And I want to assure you that the UPS team is ready to deliver another successful peak season. Now I'll turn it over to Richard.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Kate. UPS performed as we projected this quarter, with total reported revenue up about 5% and daily shipments up, almost 6%. The International segment produced another quarter of double-digit profit expansion.  And the U.S. domestic delivered resu
componenttext:
Thanks, Kate. UPS performed as we projected this quarter, with total reported revenue up about 5% and daily shipments up, almost 6%. The International segment produced another quarter of double-digit profit expansion.  And the U.S. domestic delivered results as we had anticipated, while supply chain & Freight results were somewhat below expectations.
UPS third quarter earnings per share were up about 4%. In 2016, the EPS change across the enterprise was lowered by headwinds in the U.S. domestic business and approximately $0.02 due to discrete tax credit taken in 2015.
This was a good quarter. UPS generated strong topline revenue. Great momentum in our international business and solid results from the other segments. 
Now for a closer look at how the segments performed. 
U.S. domestic revenue increased 4.8%, driven by daily package gains of 5.7%. All products contributed to volume growth, with deferred [ph] air up, more than 10%. Next Day Air up, almost 6%, and Ground, up 5.2%.  Growth was balanced from enterprise and middle market customers. 
High demand for online retailers was evident as B2C delivers were up 11%. Despite negative industrial production, B2B deliveries were up 2%, with the majority of the increase driven by our e-commerce return portfolio.
Base rate improvements were able to somewhat offset lower fuel surcharges in a drag from a changing product mix. As a result, revenue per package was up, about 1%. E-commerce customers are helping drive higher daily shipments across our entire portfolio of services,  from high single-digit growth in air products to a 20% jump in our most economical product, Sure Post. 
Even with accelerated growth of e-commerce, our investment in ORION continue to allow UPS to bend the cost curve lower and create positive return. 
ORION added efficiency again this quarter, delivery stops and volume were both up 5.7%, yet ORION have package miles to only 1.4% increase. Direct labor hours also grew slower than the average daily volume growth. 
As we guided, operating profit growth comparisons with 2015 were restrained by 1 less operating day in 2016 and higher casualty credits realized last year. Excluding these profit headwinds, operating margins expanded as we took advantage of the benefits of our investments.
Now for some details on the International segment, where we had another record, with double-digit operating profit growth for the seventh consecutive quarter. 
Profit jumped 14% as shipments climbed 7.5%. Revenue was up more than 3% on a currency-neutral basis and fuel surcharge did decline, lowering the growth rate by about 70 basis points.
U.S. export packages per day rose over 7%, growth was well-balanced on solid shipment out of Asia and across Europe. The non-U.S. domestic product increased 7.8% as we transition to pricing actions we took in 2015.
This quarter, it shows it's about getting the right volume in our network. Our International segment is delivering balanced results, with great growth and superior returns.
Let's turn a look at the supply chain and freight segment now. 
The segment produced top line growth of 8.1%, primarily driven by the Coyote acquisition. Economic conditions in the U.S. truckload and LTL market as well as the international Air Freight business continued to place downward pressure on demand. 
The [indiscernible] unit remained disciplined on revenue management and cost control, gains from the small and medium-sized customers reduced the year-over-year shortfall in total tonnage. UPS Freight has been adversely impacted by industry conditions total tonnage however, they are executing a disciplined middle market strategy which has resulted in revenue per hundredweight pricing improvement of 3.7% this quarter.
Turning to our distribution group, revenue growth was broad-based with contributions from almost all sectors. The business unit maintained its industry-leading margins in the mid-to upper single digits. 
Now to update you on our cash position. UPS again generated healthy free cash flow. Through the first 9 months, we produced $3.6 billion after investing over $1.8 billion in capital expenditures. 
Please note that we accelerate our planned discretionary pension contribution to September. This allows us to capture additional financial benefits in 2016. 
UPS also repurchased 19.5 million shares for $2 billion and paid down another $2 billion in dividends, up 7% per share over the last year. 
As we move into the fourth quarter, we anticipate total operating profit growth to be slightly higher than our full year guidance of 6% to 8%. 
Supply chain and freight is continuing to manage industry challenges. And is expected to produce a modest low single-digit revenue expansion by holding operating margins flat with last year.
For the full year, the macro environment is suppressing revenue growth. Therefore, supply chain and freight operating profit is anticipated to be slightly below 2015 levels.
We are projecting an effective tax rate for UPS of 35% in the fourth quarter. Due to the unknown, related to the mark-to-market at year-end, we are not able to provide guidance on our GAAP earnings per share. However, we are affirming our full year adjusted earnings per share guidance of $5.70 to $5.90. 
In summary, on a year-to-date basis, our business is adapting to the opportunities and challenges presented by the high-growth digital economy. We continue to reduce the industry's best margin and create free cash flow. As we look at the fourth quarter, we are confident in our ability to deliver another outstanding peak season for both our customers and our investors. 
Before we take your questions, I want to take a moment to announce our plans to hold an investor conference in early 2017. On February 21, in New York, we'll have a half day conference. David, along with the senior leaders and myself, will be on hand to lay out our recent progress and update you on our strategy. We plan to allow ample time for your questions. Later today, the IR team will send out invitations with further details. 
Thank you. And now I'll ask the operator to open the line. Operator?

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question will come from the line of Tom Wadewitz of UBS.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question will come from the line of Tom Wadewitz of UBS.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask you about the new plane order. It's an interesting topic, given you haven't ordered planes for quite a while. I want to take your thoughts on maybe the implications of that and some of the assumptions you make when you ordered long-lasting
componenttext: I wanted to ask you about the new plane order. It's an interesting topic, given you haven't ordered planes for quite a while. I want to take your thoughts on maybe the implications of that and some of the assumptions you make when you ordered long-lasting, long-lived assets like that. So does this imply that you would think that the strong growth in air volumes would continue? And then if you look out the next 5 years, is that kind of a reason, any implication? And also in terms of your largest customer who has been adding aircraft, is there an implication that you're not particularly concerned about share with the customer? So just wondered if you could talk about the kind of assumptions underlying that sizeable plane order that you announced this morning.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tom, this is Myron. When you look at it on balance, since 2008, the international export volume has grown over 40%; u.S. Domestic has had 20% growth; and our block hours are actually down over 3%. It actually speaks to our abilities to optimize our networ
componenttext: Tom, this is Myron. When you look at it on balance, since 2008, the international export volume has grown over 40%; u.S. Domestic has had 20% growth; and our block hours are actually down over 3%. It actually speaks to our abilities to optimize our networks around world, and accommodate the tremendous growth that we've seen. So going with a larger aircraft, which is the  Dash 8 [ph] , really was a smart choice for us. Obviously, given the ability to put larger plane on the lanes that have greater needs, allows us to reduce the number of frequencies for those routes. In addition to that, the Dash 8 will give us an ability to cascade capacity throughout our entire network. We plan to deploy these first aircraft into our International segment and it will allow us to bring back our current 747-400s [ph] to the U.S. that will give us capacity throughout the entire system. In addition to that, it's a much smarter choice because it allows us to take the current Dash 4 [ph] pilots who will require a very minimal amount of additional training, who can then fly the Dash 8. So we believe it was a very smart choice for us. And I'll hand it off to Alan who can talk about growth.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tom, thanks for the question. As you know, Next Day Air was up 6% this past quarter and deferred was up double-digit. Our Next Day Air growth here in the U.S. has been growing mid-single-digit for the last 5 quarters. And certainly the Second Day Air has
componenttext: Tom, thanks for the question. As you know, Next Day Air was up 6% this past quarter and deferred was up double-digit. Our Next Day Air growth here in the U.S. has been growing mid-single-digit for the last 5 quarters. And certainly the Second Day Air has grown double-digit this quarter and last year, this -- the same quarter. And you've already heard from Myron about the international growth. We've been investing significantly in our express product in terms of enhancements. As you know, this past quarter, we expanded our Express Plus time a day to 53 countries and over the year, we've expanded our express time to day to 117 countries, and we've also expanded UPS Next Day Air and UPS Next Day Air Early coverage here in the United States and in addition, also Worldwide Express rates. So we're investing significantly in the product, both domestically and internationally. And it's resonating with our customers.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And this is David. Just to wrap it up. In some places or in some cases, you'd be adding aircraft because you're retiring aircraft. This is really about opportunity. This is the estimate of what we have done in our international business and in our domesti
componenttext: And this is David. Just to wrap it up. In some places or in some cases, you'd be adding aircraft because you're retiring aircraft. This is really about opportunity. This is the estimate of what we have done in our international business and in our domestic business as far as growing our air business. Our customers are asking us for additional capacity and initiative is about. So we're really excited about it. And thank you for the question.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question will come from the line of Ken Hoexter of Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Next question will come from the line of Ken Hoexter of Merrill Lynch.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And an outlook for the supply chain, but I don't -- unless I missed it, I don't think you gave that on the domestic national outlook. So aside from the peak prep, in your targets, can you talk about your expectations for growth and costs and pricing? And
componenttext: And an outlook for the supply chain, but I don't -- unless I missed it, I don't think you gave that on the domestic national outlook. So aside from the peak prep, in your targets, can you talk about your expectations for growth and costs and pricing? And then really, I want to focus on the ability to improve margins domestically, given the e-commerce growth.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think, Ken when you first look at it, you have to start where we are, year-to-date. And right now, our earnings per share are up almost 7%. We expect our fourth quarter operating growth of profit to be slightly higher than the overall solid great
componenttext:
Sure. I think, Ken when you first look at it, you have to start where we are, year-to-date. And right now, our earnings per share are up almost 7%. We expect our fourth quarter operating growth of profit to be slightly higher than the overall solid great fourth quarter. The investments that we've made across all the segments are bringing in those returns, and we're balancing that again to make microenvironment as we talked about in supply chain and freight. At the end, when you look at what's happening and where we're going with it, it really is about International continuing to deliver on what they have really done for 7 quarters and in the Domestic, we will see margin expansion for the year. We have, as I mentioned last quarter, some change because of workdays and some year-over-year comp issues in the third quarter, but we expect the whole year that we will see a margin expansion. We'll take an online question next. This comes from Jack Atkins at Stevens. Jack really asked can we speak a little bit more about the long term capital spending over the next few years, both with the hub automation and the aircraft.
So again, this is Richard. And Jack, I think, the first and you have to remember here is that our capital policy remains consistently unchanged. Our number one priority for many years had continued to be to reinvest in the business. And you see that in our [indiscernible] having the highest return on invested capital is not only good for the enterprise, but it's also good for the shareholders. We continue to see strong returns for all the investments we've made over the last few years, we've talked about that only what we're doing in the house, but we'll also Orion and again, this quarter, we continue to see the benefits of almost a 6% volume growth and muted miles growth. And so all of that comes to the bottom line. We're always evaluating ways to look at can we accelerate some of this investment because it such high return on these investments we're making.
[Audio Gap]
We're going to actually bring everyone together in early February to really talk about where the Enterprise is going, what great opportunities we have, were we'll see growth come from and what our plans are for next you. And I think, at that time, you'll see that the future is very bright. We continue to have year-over-year improvements in margin, and that's our plan going forward as well.

headline: United Parcel Service, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
